column2:
A 6-day-old Caucasian female is brought to the pediatrician by her parents due to ongoing constipation since birth. She has not passed meconium and has been vomiting bile-stained fluid. Her mother reports she was full term with an uncomplicated pregnancy. On physical examination, the infant's abdomen is distended and tympanitic. Rectal examination reveals an explosive expulsion of gas and stool. What is the most likely diagnosis?


 Hirschsprung's disease.

 The absence of meconium passage within the first 48 hours of life, abdominal distention, vomiting, and explosive expulsion of stool upon rectal examination are classic presentations of Hirschsprung's disease.

A 2-year-old African American male is brought to the pediatrician by his mother due to recurrent episodes of constipation for the past year. He often passes hard stools with difficulty and has intermittent abdominal pain. His mother also describes episodes of vomiting. The child appears underweight. On examination, his abdomen is distended with palpable fecal mass. Rectal examination reveals a tight anal sphincter with an empty rectal vault. What is the most likely diagnosis?


 Hirschsprung's disease.

 Chronic constipation, failure to thrive, and an empty rectal vault on examination in a toddler are suggestive of Hirschsprung's disease. 

A Hispanic 1-year-old male is seen in the emergency department with his parents due to severe abdominal pain, fever, and diarrhea for the past two days. His parents report that the child has had problems with constipation since birth. Physical examination reveals a distended, tender abdomen. Rectal examination reveals an empty rectal vault. What is the most likely diagnosis?


 Hirschsprung's disease, complicated by Hirschsprung's-associated enterocolitis.

 The combination of chronic constipation, abdominal distention, fever, and diarrhea suggests Hirschsprung's-associated enterocolitis, a potentially life-threatening complication of Hirschsprung's disease.

A 6-week-old Asian female is brought to the pediatrician by her parents due to vomiting and constipation. The infant has not passed stool for the past three days and has been vomiting greenish fluid. The parents report she was born at full term. On physical examination, the infant's abdomen is distended and tympanitic. Rectal examination reveals an empty rectal vault. What is the most likely diagnosis?


 Hirschsprung's disease.

 Delayed passage of meconium, abdominal distention, and bilious vomiting in an infant are suggestive of Hirschsprung's disease.

A 3-year-old Caucasian male is brought to the pediatrician by his mother due to chronic constipation. The mother reports that the child has been having difficulty passing stools since birth and often passes hard, pebble-like stools. The child appears underweight. On physical examination, the abdomen is distended with a palpable fecal mass. Rectal examination reveals a tight anal sphincter and an empty rectal vault. What is the most likely diagnosis?


 Hirschsprung's disease.

 Chronic constipation, failure to thrive, and an empty rectal vault on examination in an older infant or young child are suggestive of Hirschsprung's disease.

column2:
A 2-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents because of severe abdominal pain for the past 3 hours. The pain is intermittent, severe, and makes him cry. Each episode lasts for about 3 minutes and then temporarily resolves. His parents also report vomiting of bile-stained material. The child seems to be in distress and keeps drawing his legs towards his abdomen. On physical examination, his abdomen is distended and shows signs of tenderness. Bowel sounds are hyperactive. The boy's past medical history is unremarkable.


 Malrotation of the intestines.

 The patient's symptoms of episodic severe abdominal pain along with vomiting of bile-stained material are indicative of an intestinal obstruction. The most common cause of this in children of this age is malrotation of the intestines leading to volvulus.

A previously healthy 7-year-old girl presents to the physician with a 2-day history of abdominal pain and vomiting. The pain started suddenly and was localized to the periumbilical region but has now become diffuse. The vomitus initially contained food particles followed by greenish liquid. Her mother reports that she has had no bowel movements for the past 2 days. On physical examination, the abdomen is distended, and bowel sounds are diminished. The past medical history, family history, and review of systems are unremarkable.


 Malrotation of the intestines.

 The child's symptoms of sudden onset abdominal pain, vomiting, and lack of bowel movements are consistent with an intestinal obstruction. Malrotation of the intestines should be suspected given her age and symptomatology. 

An 18-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of a sudden onset of severe abdominal pain and vomiting. The mother reports that he has been passing bloody stools for the past 6 hours. On physical examination, the abdomen is distended, and the child appears to be in distress. The past medical history is unremarkable and he is up to date on all his vaccinations. 


 Malrotation of the intestines.

 This child's presentation of severe abdominal pain, vomiting, and bloody stools is suggestive of an intestinal obstruction with possible bowel ischemia. The most common cause of this in children his age is malrotation of the intestines leading to volvulus.

A 5-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his parents because of a 2-day history of abdominal pain, vomiting, and constipation. The pain initially started around the belly button and has now become generalized. On physical examination, his abdomen is distended and bowel sounds are diminished. The boy's past medical history is unremarkable.


 Malrotation of the intestines.

 The patient's symptoms of pain around the belly button, vomiting, and constipation are indicative of an intestinal obstruction. The most common cause of this in children of this age is malrotation of the intestines leading to volvulus.

column2:
A 3-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician's office by his mother who reports that her son has been crying a lot more than usual and appears to be in pain. He has also been refusing to eat his food. On examination, the doctor notices a bulge in the boy's lower abdomen that becomes more prominent when he cries. The bulge is reducible and the overlying skin appears normal. 
 The most likely diagnosis is an inguinal hernia. 
This condition is common in male infants and can cause discomfort and refusal to eat due to associated pain.
A 10-year-old girl presents to the emergency department with sudden onset severe abdominal pain. The mother reports that her daughter has a history of a "bulge" in her belly button that has been present since she was a baby. On physical examination, the physician notes a swollen, tender umbilicus with a non-reducible mass. The skin over the mass is erythematous and warm to touch.
The patient most likely has an incarcerated umbilical hernia. 
The umbilical hernia has become trapped (incarcerated) and cannot be pushed back into the abdominal cavity. This cuts off the blood supply to the tissue in the hernia, a situation that requires emergency surgery.

A 12-year-old boy presents to the clinic with his father who reports that his son has been complaining of aching pain in his groin for the past week. On physical examination, a bulge is observed in the inguinal region that increases in size when the boy coughs. The bulge is easily reduced and there is no skin discoloration.
The most likely diagnosis is an inguinal hernia. 
The pain and the bulge that increases in size on coughing (due to increased intra-abdominal pressure) are characteristic features of an inguinal hernia.
A 6-month-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother who reports that her son has a swollen belly button. She noticed the swelling a few weeks ago and it seems to get bigger when he cries. On physical examination, the pediatrician identifies a soft, reducible mass in the umbilical region.
The infant has an umbilical hernia. 
This is a common condition in infants, especially those with low birth weight. The hernia usually resolves on its own by the age of 1-2 years.
An 8-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her parents. She has been complaining of severe pain in her right lower abdomen since morning. She also has a history of a "bulge" in the same region, which used to come and go. On physical examination, an irreducible mass is identified in the right inguinal region, and the overlying skin is erythematous.
The girl is suffering from an incarcerated inguinal hernia. 
The irreducible mass and severe pain suggest that the hernia has become trapped and the blood supply to the herniated tissue is compromised. This is a surgical emergency.

column2:
A 7-year-old boy presents with his mother to the clinic with complaints of severe pain in the rectal area for the past three days. His mother mentions that he has been crying during defecation and she noticed small amounts of blood on the toilet paper. His bowel movements have been normal, but he's been avoiding going to the bathroom due to the pain. The boy appears tearful and anxious. On physical examination, a small, painful tear is visible at the anal verge. 
The child is suffering from an anal fissure. 
Anal fissures are common in children. They can be caused by constipation, straining during bowel movements, or trauma. The diagnosis is typically made clinically with the hallmark symptom being severe pain during and after bowel movements. 

A 12-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her father with a two-day history of severe lower abdominal pain, which she describes as sharp and constant. She also has a fever and has vomited twice since the onset of pain. Her past medical history is unremarkable. On physical examination, the child appears acutely ill and has a temperature of 38.9C (102F). Abdominal examination reveals tenderness in the perianal area, and a fluctuant mass is palpable near the anus. 
The clinical picture is suggestive of an anal abscess. 
Anal abscesses can occur when the small glands inside the anus become infected. This can cause a cavity to form and fill with pus. The abscess can cause severe pain and fever. 

A 5-year-old boy is taken to the pediatrician by his mother because of a 3-day history of constipation and painful defecation. The mother reports observing streaks of bright red blood on the child's stool. The boy is otherwise healthy and takes no medications. On physical examination, the child is afebrile, and the abdomen is soft and non-tender. A small crack is visible on the posterior midline of the anal verge.
This is a classic presentation of an anal fissure in a child. 
Anal fissures often cause pain during and after bowel movements, blood on the surface of the stool or toilet paper, and constipation due to fear of painful defecation. 

A 14-year-old girl presents to the emergency department with severe lower abdominal pain and fever for two days. Her mother mentions that she has been complaining of pain during bowel movements for the past week, but they thought it was due to her menstrual period. On examination, the patient appears ill, with a temperature of 38.5C (101.3F). Abdominal examination shows tenderness in the perianal area, and a swollen, red, tender mass is noted near the anus.

The patient is presenting with symptoms of an anal abscess. 
Anal abscesses can cause severe pain, swelling, redness, and fever. The pain can be worsened by sitting, coughing, or bowel movements. 

A 10-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother due to a 4-day history of constipation and painful defecation. The boy also complains of a burning sensation during bowel movements. His medical history is unremarkable. Physical examination reveals a small tear at the anal verge.

This is a presentation of an anal fissure.
Anal fissures often cause pain and a burning sensation during bowel movements. They can also lead to constipation due to fear of painful defecation.

column2:
A 14-year-old girl presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of lower abdominal pain. The pain is dull and constant, rated 7/10 in severity, and exacerbated by movement. She also complains of dysuria and urinary frequency. She denies any recent sexual activity. Her past medical history is unremarkable. On physical exam, suprapubic tenderness is noted. Urinalysis reveals leukocyte esterase and nitrites. 


 Urinary tract infection (UTI)

 This patient's presentation of lower abdominal pain, dysuria, urinary frequency, and positive urinalysis is consistent with a UTI.

A 6-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his mother who reports that he has been complaining of abdominal pain for the past day. The pain is located in the lower abdomen and is associated with a fever. The boy also complains of burning sensation while urinating. He has no history of similar symptoms. On physical examination, he is febrile with a temperature of 101.2F, and tenderness to palpation is noted in the lower abdomen. Urinalysis shows positive leukocyte esterase and nitrites. 


 Urinary tract infection (UTI)

 The boy's symptoms of lower abdominal pain, fever, dysuria, and positive urinalysis are indicative of a UTI.

A 10-year-old girl presents to the clinic with a 3-day history of pain in the lower abdomen. She reports frequent urination and discomfort during urination. She also mentions a low-grade fever for the past two days. Her past medical history is significant for multiple UTIs. On physical exam, the lower abdomen is tender to palpation. Urinalysis reveals leukocyte esterase and nitrites.


 Urinary tract infection (UTI)

 The patient's symptoms of lower abdominal pain, dysuria, urinary frequency, fever, and positive urinalysis, along with her history of UTIs, suggest a recurrent UTI.

A 12-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother due to a 1-day history of abdominal pain. The pain is described as being lower in location, with a burning sensation during urination. He also reports urinary urgency. His past medical history is unremarkable. On physical examination, suprapubic tenderness is noted. Urinalysis shows leukocyte esterase and nitrites.


 Urinary tract infection (UTI)

 The boy's symptoms of lower abdominal pain, dysuria, urinary urgency, and positive urinalysis are indicative of a UTI.

An 8-year-old girl presents to the pediatrician with her mother who reports that her daughter has been complaining of abdominal pain for the past two days. The pain is located in the lower abdomen and is associated with a fever. The girl also complains of a burning sensation while urinating. Her past medical history is significant for vesicoureteral reflux. On physical examination, the lower abdomen is tender to palpation. Urinalysis reveals leukocyte esterase and nitrites. 


 Urinary tract infection (UTI)

 The patient's symptoms of lower abdominal pain, dysuria, fever, and positive urinalysis, along with a history of vesicoureteral reflux, suggest a UTI.

column2:
A 13-year-old Caucasian boy presents with sudden, severe pain in his right lower abdomen that has been persisting for the past 6 hours. The pain radiates to his groin. He also reports nausea but no vomiting. He denies any urinary symptoms. On examination, he appears uncomfortable and is found to have a positive right costovertebral angle tenderness. Urinalysis is positive for microscopic hematuria.

 Kidney stones

 This patient's sudden onset of colicky flank pain radiating to the groin, positive CVA tenderness, and hematuria are suggestive of renal colic due to kidney stones.

A 10-year-old Hispanic girl comes to the clinic with her mother complaining of intermittent abdominal pain for the past two weeks. The pain is severe and is located in her right lower quadrant. She also reports that her urine is pink. She denies fever, vomiting, or change in bowel habits. On examination, her vitals are stable, and abdominal examination reveals right lower quadrant tenderness without rebound or guarding. Urinalysis shows red blood cells.

 Kidney stones

 The intermittent, severe abdominal pain and hematuria in this child are suggestive of a kidney stone.

A 12-year-old African American boy presents with intermittent severe pain in his left flank that comes and goes. The pain has increased in severity over the past few days, and he has noticed that his urine is darker than usual. He denies any fever, chills, or weight loss. Physical examination reveals left costovertebral angle tenderness. Urinalysis is positive for hematuria.

 Kidney stones

 The intermittent, severe flank pain and hematuria suggest a kidney stone.

A 16-year-old Caucasian girl presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of severe left-sided abdominal pain. The pain is sharp, radiates to her back, and is associated with nausea. She has a past medical history of recurrent urinary tract infections. On examination, her abdomen is tender to palpation in the left upper quadrant without rebound or guarding. Urinalysis reveals red blood cells and white blood cells.

 Kidney stones

 This patient's history of recurrent urinary tract infections, combined with her current symptoms of severe flank pain and hematuria, suggest a kidney stone.

A 9-year-old Hispanic boy presents with a 3-day history of lower abdominal pain and frequent urination. He also reports that his urine has been dark. There is no history of fever, nausea, or vomiting. On examination, his vitals are stable, and he has tenderness in the suprapubic area. Urinalysis shows red blood cells and white blood cells.

 Kidney stones

 The lower abdominal pain, frequency, and hematuria in this child suggest a kidney stone.

An 11-year-old Caucasian girl presents to the clinic with intermittent right-sided abdominal pain that has been occurring for the past month. The pain is colicky in nature and radiates to her groin. She also reports dysuria but denies any fever, nausea, or vomiting. On examination, she has right lower quadrant tenderness. Urinalysis reveals microscopic hematuria.

 Kidney stones

 This patient's colicky, radiating abdominal pain and hematuria are suggestive of a kidney stone.

A 14-year-old Asian boy presents with intense pain in his left lower quadrant that started suddenly last night. The pain is severe and radiates to the groin. He also reports nausea and vomiting. Physical examination reveals tenderness in the left lower quadrant, and urinalysis shows microscopic hematuria.

 Kidney stones

 The sudden onset of severe, radiating abdominal pain and hematuria in this child are indicative of a kidney stone.

A 15-year-old Caucasian boy presents with a 2-day history of intermittent and severe right flank pain. The pain radiates to his groin and is associated with nausea and vomiting. He has a past medical history of cystinuria. On examination, he appears uncomfortable and is found to have right costovertebral angle tenderness. Urinalysis reveals microscopic hematuria and cystine crystals.

 Kidney stones

 The patient's cystinuria, a condition that causes cystine stones, combined with his symptoms of colicky flank pain and hematuria, suggest a kidney stone.

A 12-year-old African American girl presents with severe left-sided abdominal pain and vomiting. The pain started suddenly last night and has been getting worse. She also reports that her urine has been dark. On examination, the abdomen is tender on the left side. Urinalysis reveals red blood cells and white blood cells.

 Kidney stones

 The severe abdominal pain, hematuria, and pyuria in this child are suggestive of a kidney stone.


A 14-year-old Hispanic girl presents with a 3-day history of lower abdominal pain and frequent urination. She also reports that her urine has been dark. There is no history of fever, nausea, or vomiting. On examination, her vitals are stable, and she has tenderness in the suprapubic area. Urinalysis shows red blood cells and white blood cells.

 Kidney stones

 The lower abdominal pain, frequency, and hematuria in this child suggest a kidney stone.


A 13-year-old Caucasian boy presents with a 1-week history of intermittent and severe left flank pain. The pain is colicky in nature and radiates to his groin. He has a past medical history of hypercalciuria. On examination, he appears uncomfortable and is found to have left costovertebral angle tenderness. Urinalysis reveals microscopic hematuria and calcium oxalate crystals.

 Kidney stones

 This patient's hypercalciuria, a condition that causes calcium oxalate stones, combined with his symptoms of colicky flank pain and hematuria, suggest a kidney stone.

column47: The lower abdominal pain, frequency, and hematuria in this child suggest a kidney stone.
column48: An 11-year-old Caucasian girl presents to the clinic with intermittent right-sided abdominal pain that has been occurring for the past month. The pain is colicky in nature and radiates to her groin. She also reports dysuria but denies any fever, nausea, or vomiting. On examination, she has right lower quadrant tenderness. Urinalysis reveals microscopic hematuria.
column50: This patient's colicky, radiating abdominal pain and hematuria are suggestive of a kidney stone.
column51: A 14-year-old Asian boy presents with intense pain in his left lower quadrant that started suddenly last night. The pain is severe and radiates to the groin. He also reports nausea and vomiting. Physical examination reveals tenderness in the left lower quadrant, and urinalysis shows microscopic hematuria.
column53: The sudden onset of severe, radiating abdominal pain and hematuria in this child are indicative of a kidney stone.
column54: A 16-year-old Caucasian boy presents with a 2-day history of intermittent and severe right flank pain. The pain radiates to his groin and is associated with nausea and vomiting. He has a past medical history of cystinuria. On examination, he appears uncomfortable and is found to have right costovertebral angle tenderness. Urinalysis reveals microscopic hematuria and cystine crystals.
column56: The patient's cystinuria, a condition that causes cystine stones, combined with his symptoms of colicky flank pain and hematuria, suggest a kidney stone.
column57: A 12-year-old African American girl presents with severe left-sided abdominal pain and vomiting. The pain started suddenly last night and has been getting worse. She also reports that her urine has been dark. On examination, the abdomen is tender on the left side. Urinalysis reveals red blood cells and white blood cells.
column59: The severe abdominal pain, hematuria, and pyuria in this child are suggestive of a kidney stone.
column60: A 14-year-old Hispanic girl presents with a 3-day history of lower abdominal pain and frequent urination. She also reports that her urine has been dark. There is no history of fever, nausea, or vomiting. On examination, her vitals are stable, and she has tenderness in the suprapubic area. Urinalysis shows red blood cells and white blood cells.
column62: The lower abdominal pain, frequency, and hematuria in this child suggest a kidney stone.

column2:
A 12-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of severe, intermittent abdominal pain for the past 5 hours. The pain is located in the right lower quadrant and radiates to the groin. The mother reports that the boy has been vomiting and has also complained of occasional pain while urinating. His past medical history is unremarkable. On physical examination, there is tenderness in the right lower quadrant but no rebound or guarding. Urinalysis shows microscopic hematuria. What is the most likely diagnosis?


 Kidney stones

 The patient's severe, colicky abdominal pain radiating to the groin, associated vomiting, and hematuria suggest ureterolithiasis. Kidney stones are less common in children than in adults but they can still occur.

An 8-year-old girl is brought to the clinic by her father due to 3 episodes of sudden, severe left-sided abdominal pain over the past week. The pain subsides after a few hours. The girl also complains of frequency and pain during urination. Her father reports that the girl has been drinking less water lately. On physical examination, the left flank is tender to palpation. Urinalysis reveals red blood cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?


 Kidney stones

 The girl's intermittent severe abdominal pain, dysuria, and positive urinalysis for blood suggest renal calculi. Dehydration, as suggested by decreased water intake, can increase the risk of stone formation.

A 10-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with his mother, complaining of severe abdominal pain that woke him up from sleep. The pain is located in the right lower quadrant and is associated with nausea. The patient has a history of cystic fibrosis. On physical examination, there is tenderness in the right lower quadrant. Urinalysis is positive for microscopic hematuria. What is the most likely diagnosis?


 Kidney stones

 Kidney stones can be a complication of cystic fibrosis due to the increased sodium and chloride content in the urine, which promotes stone formation. The patient's colicky abdominal pain and hematuria are indicative of ureterolithiasis.

A 14-year-old obese girl is brought to the clinic by her mother because of recurrent episodes of right-sided flank pain for the past month. The pain is severe, comes in waves, and radiates to the groin. The girl also complains of urgency and frequency of urination. On physical examination, there is tenderness in the right flank. Urinalysis shows microscopic hematuria and crystals. What is the most likely diagnosis?


 Kidney stones

 The patient's obesity increases her risk for kidney stone formation. Her symptoms of renal colic and positive urinalysis findings suggest the presence of renal calculi.

A 7-year-old boy with a history of Down syndrome is brought to the emergency department by his parents due to sudden, severe right-sided abdominal pain for the past 6 hours. The pain is associated with nausea and vomiting. On physical examination, the right lower quadrant is tender to palpation. Urinalysis is positive for red blood cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?


 Kidney stones

 Down syndrome is associated with hypercalciuria, which can lead to kidney stone formation. The boy's symptoms and urinalysis findings suggest the presence of a kidney stone.

column2:
A 14-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother for severe left-sided abdominal pain that started suddenly earlier today. The pain is intermittent, colicky in nature, and radiates to the groin. He denies any fever, nausea, or vomiting. He has no significant past medical history but his father had similar episodes of abdominal pain in his teenage years. Physical examination shows a well-appearing boy in distress. He has tenderness in the left lower quadrant with no rebound or guarding. Urinalysis shows microscopic hematuria. 


 Kidney stones

 The clinical picture is suggestive of nephrolithiasis (kidney stones). The patient's symptoms of severe, colicky abdominal pain radiating to the groin, along with microscopic hematuria, are classic for kidney stones. A family history of kidney stones can also increase the risk.

A 16-year-old girl presents with a 2-day history of right-sided abdominal pain. She describes the pain as sharp and cramping, and notes it becomes worse when she moves. She also reports nausea but no vomiting or changes in bowel movements. She has a history of recurrent urinary tract infections. On physical examination, she is afebrile and has right flank tenderness. Urinalysis reveals RBCs and a few WBCs. 


 Kidney stones

 The patient's symptoms of sharp, crampy abdominal pain and nausea, along with a history of recurrent urinary tract infections and the presence of RBCs and WBCs in the urine, are suggestive of nephrolithiasis. Recurrent urinary tract infections can lead to struvite stone formation.

A 12-year-old boy with a history of cystic fibrosis presents with severe intermittent abdominal pain that woke him from sleep. The pain is located in the right lower quadrant and radiates to the groin. He also reports feeling nauseous. Examination reveals tenderness in the right lower quadrant. Urinalysis shows hematuria and crystals in the urine. 


 Kidney stones

 This patient's severe, intermittent abdominal pain radiating to the groin, nausea, and the presence of hematuria and crystals in the urine are indicative of nephrolithiasis. Cystic fibrosis patients have an increased risk of kidney stones due to their chronic dehydration status and abnormal mineral metabolism.

A 15-year-old girl presents with sudden onset of severe, sharp pain in her lower abdomen that started this morning. The pain is intermittent and radiates to her back. She also has nausea but no vomiting. She has a history of bariatric surgery for obesity 6 months ago. Physical exam reveals left lower quadrant tenderness. Urinalysis shows microscopic hematuria and urine pH is 7.5.


 Kidney stones

 This patient's severe, intermittent abdominal pain radiating to the back, nausea, and the presence of microscopic hematuria and alkaline urine are suggestive of nephrolithiasis. Bariatric surgery patients are at increased risk of kidney stones due to changes in urinary pH and increased urinary excretion of oxalate.

A 13-year-old boy with no significant past medical history presents with severe left lower quadrant pain that started suddenly last night. The pain is sharp and intermittent, and is associated with nausea and vomiting. His father had a history of kidney stones. On physical examination, he is in distress and has left lower quadrant tenderness. Urinalysis shows microscopic hematuria.


 Kidney stones

 The patient's symptoms of severe, intermittent abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting, along with microscopic hematuria and family history of kidney stones, are suggestive of nephrolithiasis. The sharp, intermittent nature of the pain is characteristic of renal colic caused by kidney stones.

column2:
1. A 10-year-old African American girl presents to the emergency department with severe intermittent right lower quadrant pain for the past 2 days. She also reports nausea, vomiting, and decreased appetite. Physical examination reveals tenderness in the right lower quadrant without rebound or guarding. There is no history of trauma, and her bowel movements are normal. 
The answer is kidney stones. 
The patient's symptoms of right lower quadrant pain, nausea, and vomiting are classic for kidney stones. 

2. A 14-year-old Caucasian boy presents to the clinic with acute left flank pain that radiates to the groin. He also reports painful urination and has seen blood in his urine. His father has a history of kidney stones. Physical examination reveals left costovertebral angle tenderness. 
The answer is kidney stones. 
This patient's left flank pain radiation to the groin, hematuria, and a family history of kidney stones are suggestive of nephrolithiasis.

He also reports nausea and vomiting. His parents report a history of dark yellow urine for the past week. Physical examination reveals a palpable mass in the right lower quadrant. 
The answer is kidney stones. 
The colicky abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and dark yellow urine suggest nephrolithiasis.

column62: His symptoms of left flank pain, nausea, vomiting, hematuria, and a family history of kidney stones suggest nephrolithiasis.

column2:
A 10-year-old African American boy presents to the emergency department with severe pain in the right lower quadrant of his abdomen which started suddenly a few hours ago. He also reports nausea and has vomited once today. The pain is sharp, intermittent, and radiates to his groin. Examination reveals tenderness over the right lumbar region and the right lower quadrant. Urinalysis shows microscopic hematuria. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 Kidney stones.

 The sudden onset of severe pain, nausea, vomiting, and microscopic hematuria in a child with abdominal pain is highly suggestive of kidney stones.

A 14-year-old Caucasian girl presents to the clinic with recurrent episodes of moderate to severe abdominal pain over the past six months. The pain is usually in the right lower quadrant, comes and goes, and sometimes radiates to the right lower back. She also reports cloudy urine and an episode of visible blood in her urine last month. Physical examination is unremarkable except for mild tenderness in the right lower quadrant. Urinalysis shows crystals and red blood cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 Kidney stones.

 The presence of crystals and red blood cells in the urine, along with the history of intermittent abdominal pain, suggests kidney stones.

 Kidney stones.

 The sudden onset of severe colicky flank pain with nausea, vomiting, and microscopic hematuria is highly suggestive of kidney stones.

A 12-year-old Asian girl presents with recurrent episodes of sharp pain in the lower abdomen over the past year. The pain is intermittent, severe, and radiates to the back. She also reports frequent urination and occasional blood in her urine. Physical examination is unremarkable except for mild tenderness in the lower abdomen. Urinalysis shows crystals and red blood cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 Kidney stones.

 The presence of crystals and red blood cells in the urine, along with the history of intermittent abdominal and back pain, suggests kidney stones.

column2:
A 14-year-old Caucasian boy presents to the emergency department complaining of severe, sharp pain in the right lower quadrant of his abdomen. The pain started suddenly and has been constant since its onset. The child has been vomiting and appears pale. He denies any recent trauma or fever. On physical examination, he is afebrile, with a pulse of 110 beats per minute and a blood pressure of 130/85 mmHg. His abdomen is tender to palpation in the right lower quadrant with positive rebound tenderness. His right testicle appears normal and there is no hernia evident. Urinalysis shows microscopic hematuria.


 Kidney stones

 The sudden onset of severe, sharp, and constant pain in the right lower quadrant, along with vomiting, suggests renal colic, which is typically caused by kidney stones. The presence of microscopic hematuria in the urinalysis further supports this diagnosis. The absence of fever and normal testicle on examination rule out conditions such as appendicitis, testicular torsion, and inguinal hernia.

A 12-year-old African American girl with a history of sickle cell disease presents to the emergency department with severe, cramping pain in her lower abdomen that has been progressively worsening over the past few hours. She also reports increased frequency of urination and a burning sensation during urination. She denies any fever, vomiting, or diarrhea. On physical examination, she is afebrile, with a pulse of 90 beats per minute and a blood pressure of 120/80 mmHg. Her abdomen is tender to palpation in the suprapubic region. Urinalysis shows microscopic hematuria and no evidence of infection.


 Kidney stones

 The severe, cramping lower abdominal pain, along with increased frequency of urination and dysuria, suggests urinary tract pathology. The presence of microscopic hematuria in the urinalysis further supports this diagnosis. The absence of fever and negative urinalysis for infection rule out conditions such as urinary tract infection and pyelonephritis. Patients with sickle cell disease are at increased risk for developing kidney stones due to the increased concentration of red blood cells and their byproducts in the urine.

A 16-year-old Hispanic boy with no significant past medical history presents to the emergency department with severe, sharp pain in his left flank that started suddenly a few hours ago. The pain radiates to his lower abdomen and is associated with nausea and vomiting. He denies any trauma, fever, or changes in bowel habits. On physical examination, he is afebrile, with a pulse of 100 beats per minute and a blood pressure of 125/85 mmHg. His abdomen is tender to palpation in the left flank and lower quadrant, with no rebound tenderness or guarding. Urinalysis shows microscopic hematuria.


 Kidney stones

 The sudden onset of severe, sharp, left flank pain that radiates to the lower abdomen, along with nausea and vomiting, suggests renal colic, which is typically caused by kidney stones. The presence of microscopic hematuria in the urinalysis further supports this diagnosis. The absence of fever, rebound tenderness, and guarding rules out conditions such as diverticulitis and appendicitis.

A 10-year-old Asian girl presents to the pediatric clinic with a 1-day history of dull, aching pain in her right lower abdomen. The pain is constant and not related to meals or activity. She has also noticed that her urine is darker than usual. She denies any fever, vomiting, or changes in bowel habits. On physical examination, she is afebrile, with a pulse of 85 beats per minute and a blood pressure of 115/75 mmHg. Her abdomen is tender to palpation in the right lower quadrant, with no rebound tenderness or guarding. Urinalysis shows microscopic hematuria and no evidence of infection.


 Kidney stones

 The dull, aching right lower abdominal pain, along with dark urine, suggests a urinary tract pathology. The presence of microscopic hematuria in the urinalysis further supports this diagnosis. The absence of fever and negative urinalysis for infection rule out conditions such as urinary tract infection and appendicitis.

A 14-year-old Caucasian girl with a history of Crohn's disease presents to the pediatric clinic with a 2-day history of severe, sharp pain in her left lower abdomen. The pain is constant and has been worsening. She has also noticed that her urine is darker than usual. She denies any fever, vomiting, or changes in bowel habits. On physical examination, she is afebrile, with a pulse of 90 beats per minute and a blood pressure of 120/80 mmHg. Her abdomen is tender to palpation in the left lower quadrant, with no rebound tenderness or guarding. Urinalysis shows microscopic hematuria and no evidence of infection.


 Kidney stones

 The severe, sharp left lower abdominal pain, along with dark urine, suggests a urinary tract pathology. The presence of microscopic hematuria in the urinalysis further supports this diagnosis. Patients with Crohn's disease are at increased risk for developing kidney stones due to malabsorption of fats which bind to calcium in the gut, leaving oxalate free to be absorbed and deposited in the kidney. The absence of fever and negative urinalysis for infection rule out conditions such as urinary tract infection and Crohn's disease exacerbation.

column2:
A 15-year-old Hispanic female presents to the ER accompanied by her mother, complaining of severe right-sided flank pain that started suddenly this morning. The pain is described as constant, dull, radiating to the lower abdomen and associated with fever and chills. She also reports dysuria, urgency, and frequency. She has no history of urinary tract infections. On examination, there is right costovertebral angle tenderness and a temperature of 38.9 C. Urinalysis is positive for leukocyte esterase and nitrites.


 Acute Pyelonephritis

 The patient's symptoms, physical examination findings, and urinalysis results are consistent with acute pyelonephritis which is a bacterial infection of the renal parenchyma caused commonly by gram-negative organisms like E.coli.

An 8-year-old African American boy is brought to the pediatrician's office by his parents for a 2-day history of left-sided abdominal pain, fever, and vomiting. His mother mentions that he has been urinating more frequently and complains of a burning sensation during urination. He has no past medical history. On examination, he appears ill, has left costovertebral angle tenderness and a temperature of 39.2 C. Urinalysis shows white blood cells and bacteria. 


 Acute Pyelonephritis

 This child's symptoms, physical examination findings, and urinalysis results suggest acute pyelonephritis. Frequent urination and dysuria are suggestive of lower urinary tract infection, however, the presence of systemic symptoms like fever, vomiting, and flank pain indicates upper urinary tract infection i.e., pyelonephritis. 

A 16-year-old Caucasian girl presents to the ER with a 1-day history of right-sided flank pain, fever, and chills. She also complains of nausea and has vomited twice today. She had a urinary tract infection 3 months ago. On examination, she is febrile with a temperature of 38.7 C and has right costovertebral angle tenderness. Urinalysis reveals white blood cells and bacteria.


 Acute Pyelonephritis

 This patient's history of urinary tract infection, current symptoms, physical examination findings, and urinalysis results are suggestive of acute pyelonephritis. Recurrent urinary tract infections can be a risk factor for the development of pyelonephritis.

A 12-year-old Asian boy is brought to the pediatrician's office by his mother, complaining of intermittent left-sided abdominal pain for the past 2 days. He also reports fever, chills, and dysuria. He has a history of vesicoureteral reflux diagnosed at age 5. On physical examination, he is febrile with a temperature of 38.9 C and has left costovertebral angle tenderness. Urinalysis is positive for leukocyte esterase and nitrites.


 Acute Pyelonephritis

 This patient's history of vesicoureteral reflux, current symptoms, physical examination findings, and urinalysis results are indicative of acute pyelonephritis. Vesicoureteral reflux is a major risk factor for pyelonephritis as it allows the retrograde flow of bacteria from the bladder into the kidneys.

A 14-year-old Native American girl presents to the ER with a 2-day history of generalized abdominal pain, more severe on the right side, accompanied by fever, nausea, and vomiting. She also reports frequent, painful urination. Her past medical history is significant for recurrent urinary tract infections. On physical examination, she is febrile with a temperature of 39.1 C and has right costovertebral angle tenderness. Urinalysis shows pyuria and bacteriuria.


 Acute Pyelonephritis

 This patient's history of recurrent urinary tract infections, current symptoms, physical examination findings, and urinalysis results are suggestive of acute pyelonephritis. Recurrent urinary tract infections increase the risk of pyelonephritis.
column3: A 15-year-old Hispanic female presents to the ER accompanied by her mother, complaining of severe right-sided flank pain that started suddenly this morning. The pain is described as constant, dull, radiating to the lower abdomen and associated with fever and chills. She also reports dysuria, urgency, and frequency. She has no history of urinary tract infections. On examination, there is right costovertebral angle tenderness and a temperature of 38.9 C. Urinalysis is positive for leukocyte esterase and nitrites.
column5: The patient's symptoms, physical examination findings, and urinalysis results are consistent with acute pyelonephritis which is a bacterial infection of the renal parenchyma caused commonly by gram-negative organisms like E.coli.
column6: An 8-year-old African American boy is brought to the pediatrician's office by his parents for a 2-day history of left-sided abdominal pain, fever, and vomiting. His mother mentions that he has been urinating more frequently and complains of a burning sensation during urination. He has no past medical history. On examination, he appears ill, has left costovertebral angle tenderness and a temperature of 39.2 C. Urinalysis shows white blood cells and bacteria.
column8: This child's symptoms, physical examination findings, and urinalysis results suggest acute pyelonephritis. Frequent urination and dysuria are suggestive of lower urinary tract infection, however, the presence of systemic symptoms like fever, vomiting, and flank pain indicates upper urinary tract infection i.e., pyelonephritis.
column9: A 16-year-old Caucasian girl presents to the ER with a 1-day history of right-sided flank pain, fever, and chills. She also complains of nausea and has vomited twice today. She had a urinary tract infection 3 months ago. On examination, she is febrile with a temperature of 38.7 C and has right costovertebral angle tenderness. Urinalysis reveals white blood cells and bacteria.
column11: This patient's history of urinary tract infection, current symptoms, physical examination findings, and urinalysis results are suggestive of acute pyelonephritis. Recurrent urinary tract infections can be a risk factor for the development of pyelonephritis.
column12: A 12-year-old Asian boy is brought to the pediatrician's office by his mother, complaining of intermittent left-sided abdominal pain for the past 2 days. He also reports fever, chills, and dysuria. He has a history of vesicoureteral reflux diagnosed at age 5. On physical examination, he is febrile with a temperature of 38.9 C and has left costovertebral angle tenderness. Urinalysis is positive for leukocyte esterase and nitrites.
column14: This patient's history of vesicoureteral reflux, current symptoms, physical examination findings, and urinalysis results are indicative of acute pyelonephritis. Vesicoureteral reflux is a major risk factor for pyelonephritis as it allows the retrograde flow of bacteria from the bladder into the kidneys.
column15: A 14-year-old Native American girl presents to the ER with a 2-day history of generalized abdominal pain, more severe on the right side, accompanied by fever, nausea, and vomiting. She also reports frequent, painful urination. Her past medical history is significant for recurrent urinary tract infections. On physical examination, she is febrile with a temperature of 39.1 C and has right costovertebral angle tenderness. Urinalysis shows pyuria and bacteriuria.
column17: This patient's history of recurrent urinary tract infections, current symptoms, physical examination findings, and urinalysis results are suggestive of acute pyelonephritis. Recurrent urinary tract infections increase the risk of pyelonephritis.

1. A 12-year-old girl presents to the emergency department with her mother, complaining of severe pain in her lower back and lower abdomen. She also mentions that she has been feeling feverish and has been vomiting. She has a history of recurrent urinary tract infections. Physical exam reveals tenderness to percussion over the costovertebral angle. Urinalysis shows leukocyte esterase and nitrites. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Pyelonephritis. 
The recurrent UTIs, fever, vomiting, flank pain, and urinary findings are consistent with this diagnosis.
2. A 7-year-old boy presents with high fever, chills, and lower abdominal pain for the past 2 days. His mother reports that he has been urinating frequently and complains of pain during urination. On physical exam, he has costovertebral angle tenderness. Urinalysis demonstrates pyuria and bacteriuria. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Pyelonephritis. 
The child's symptoms of urinary frequency, dysuria, fever and back pain, combined with the urinary findings, are suggestive of this diagnosis.
3. A 9-year-old girl is brought to the clinic by her parents. She has been complaining of fever, nausea, vomiting, and pain in her lower back for the past 3 days. Urinalysis shows proteinuria, hematuria, and white blood cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Pyelonephritis
The history of vesicoureteral reflux increases the likelihood of urinary tract infections ascending to the kidneys.

Pyelonephritis. 
His history of recurrent urinary tract infections and current symptoms suggest an upper urinary tract infection.

column2:
1. A 3-year-old African American girl is brought to the emergency department by her mother due to a high fever, vomiting, and right flank pain. Her mother also says the girl has been complaining of pain during urination. On physical examination, the girl is lethargic and has a temperature of 102.2F. Her abdomen is tender on the right side and she winces when the area is lightly palpated. The urinalysis shows white blood cells and bacteria. What is the likely diagnosis?
 Pyelonephritis. 
This patient's fever, flank pain, and dysuria suggest a urinary tract infection, which has likely ascended to the kidneys causing pyelonephritis.
2. A 6-year-old Caucasian boy is brought to the pediatrician by his parents due to persistent abdominal pain and occasional vomiting. He has not had a fever. On examination, he has tenderness in the left lower quadrant of his abdomen, without any signs of peritonitis. His urinalysis comes back positive for leukocytes and nitrites. What is the most likely explanation for his symptoms?
 Pyelonephritis. 
The presence of leukocytes and nitrites in the urine indicates a urinary tract infection. The abdominal pain and vomiting suggest that the infection has ascended to the kidney.
3. A 10-year-old Hispanic girl presents to the emergency department with her parents, complaining of severe abdominal pain and high fever. She has also been urinating frequently and complains of pain while doing so. On physical examination, costovertebral angle tenderness is noted. Laboratory findings show elevated white blood cell count and urinalysis reveals pus cells and bacteria. What is the most likely diagnosis?   
 Pyelonephritis. 
This patient's urinary symptoms, fever, abdominal pain, and positive urinalysis are consistent with a urinary tract infection that has ascended to the kidneys.
4. A 3-year-old Asian boy is brought to the doctor by his mother because of a 2-day history of abdominal pain, fever, and vomiting. The mother also reports that the boy has been crying when he urinates. Physical examination reveals right-sided abdominal tenderness. Urinalysis shows leukocytes and bacteria. What is the most likely diagnosis?
 Pyelonephritis. 
This child's symptoms and urinalysis findings are indicative of a urinary tract infection that has progressed to involve the kidneys.
5. A 7-year-old African American boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents complaining of severe abdominal pain and fever for the past 2 days. The parents also report that the boy has been urinating more frequently and complains of pain during urination. On examination, there is tenderness in the right lower quadrant. Urinalysis reveals leukocyte esterase and nitrite positivity. What is the most likely diagnosis?
 Pyelonephritis. 
The boy's symptoms of fever, abdominal pain, dysuria, and urinary frequency, along with the urinary findings, suggest that he has an upper urinary tract infection, or pyelonephritis.
6. An 8-year-old Caucasian girl is brought to the pediatrician by her parents due to a week-long history of low-grade fever, vomiting, and intermittent abdominal pain. She has also been complaining of pain during urination. On physical examination, she has a temperature of 100.4F and tenderness in the left lower quadrant of her abdomen. Urinalysis shows leukocytes and bacteria. What is the most likely diagnosis?
 Pyelonephritis. 
The girl's symptoms and urinalysis findings are suggestive of a urinary tract infection that has ascended to the kidneys
7. A 5-year-old Hispanic girl is brought to the emergency department by her mother because of a 3-day history of high fever, abdominal pain, and vomiting. On examination, the girl is lethargic, her temperature is 102.2F, and she has right-sided abdominal tenderness. Urinalysis reveals leukocytes and bacteria. What is the most likely diagnosis?
 Pyelonephritis. 
The girl symptoms and urinalysis findings suggest a urinary tract infection that has spread to the kidneys
8. A 13-year-old Asian boy presents to the pediatrician complaining of abdominal pain, particularly on the right side. He also reports frequent urination and a burning sensation during urination. His temperature is 100.8F, and physical examination reveals right-sided abdominal tenderness. Urinalysis shows leukocytes and bacteria. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Pyelonephritis. 
His symptoms and urinalysis findings are indicative of a urinary tract infection that has spread to the kidneys.
9. A 4-year-old African American girl is brought to the emergency department by her mother because of severe abdominal pain, fever, and vomiting. The mother also reports that the girl has been crying during urination. Urinalysis reveals the presence of leukocytes and bacteria. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Pyelonephritis. 
The girl's symptoms and urinalysis findings suggest a urinary tract infection that has ascended to the kidneys.
10. A 6-year-old Caucasian boy presents to the pediatrician complaining of lower abdominal pain and frequent urination. His mother also reports that he has had a fever for the past few days. Physical examination reveals left-sided abdominal tenderness. Urinalysis shows leukocytes and bacteria. What is the most likely diagnosis?   
Pyelonephritis. 
The boy's symptoms and urinalysis findings are indicative of a urinary tract infection that has spread to the kidney.

column2:
1. A 3-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her parents due to 2 days of fever and abdominal pain. The parents also report that she has been crying during urination. On physical examination, she has a temperature of 38.5 degrees Celsius and tenderness in her left flank. Urinalysis shows leukocyte esterase and nitrites. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Pyelonephritis. 
The fever, abdominal pain, and dysuria suggest a urinary tract infection, and the flank pain and fever suggest that it has ascended to involve the kidneys.
2. A 12-year-old boy presents to the clinic with complaints of lower abdominal pain and fever for the past 3 days. He also reports a burning sensation during urination. On physical exam, he is febrile with left costovertebral angle tenderness. Urinalysis shows pyuria and bacteriuria. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Pyelonephritis. 
The patient's symptoms of dysuria, abdominal pain, and fever along with the physical exam and urinalysis findings are consistent with a urinary tract infection that has ascended to the kidneys.
3. A 5-year-old girl presents with a 2-day history of fever and abdominal pain. She has also been experiencing nausea and has vomited twice. On examination, her temperature is 38.7 degrees Celsius and she appears ill. She has tenderness in the right flank and her urine has a strong smell. Urinalysis shows many white blood cells and positive nitrites. What is the most likely diagnosis?
 Pyelonephritis. 
Her symptoms, examination findings and urinalysis results are consistent with an upper urinary tract infection.
4. A 10-year-old boy is brought to the clinic with a 3-day history of fever, vomiting, and right-sided abdominal pain that radiates to the back. On examination, he is febrile and there is tenderness in the right costovertebral angle. A urinalysis reveals pyuria and hematuria. What is the most likely diagnosis?
 Pyelonephritis. 
The presence of fever, flank pain, and pyuria with hematuria in urine analysis suggest an upper urinary tract infection.
5. A 1-year-old girl is brought to the clinic by her parents due to a 2-day history of vomiting and poor feeding. She has been irritable and has had a fever. On physical examination, she is febrile and dehydrated, with left costovertebral angle tenderness. Urinalysis shows white blood cells and bacteria. What could be the diagnosis?
 Pyelonephritis. 
The infant's fever, irritability, poor feeding, and vomiting along with costovertebral angle tenderness and urinalysis findings suggest a urinary tract infection that has ascended to the kidneys.
6. A 6-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department due to a 2-day history of fever, abdominal pain, and increased frequency of urination. On physical examination, she is febrile and there is tenderness in the lower abdomen and left flank. Urinalysis shows leukocyte esterase and nitrites. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Pyelonephritis. 
The patient's symptoms of dysuria, abdominal pain, and fever along with the physical exam and urinalysis findings are indicative of a urinary tract infection that has ascended to the kidneys.
7. A 4-year-old boy presents with a 3-day history of fever, right-sided abdominal pain that radiates to the back, and reduced appetite. On examination, he is febrile and there is tenderness in the right costovertebral angle. A urinalysis reveals pyuria and bacteria. What is the most likely diagnosis?
 Pyelonephritis. 
The presence of fever, flank pain, and pyuria with bacteria in urine analysis suggest an upper urinary tract infection.

The patient's symptoms of dysuria, abdominal pain, and fever along with the physical exam and urinalysis findings are consistent with a urinary tract infection that has ascended to the kidneys.

The infant's fever, irritability, poor feeding, and vomiting, along with costovertebral angle tenderness and urinalysis findings, suggest a urinary tract infection that has ascended to the kidneys.

column2:
1. A 5-year-old girl is brought to the clinic with a 2-day history of abdominal pain and vomiting. She also complains of a burning sensation during urination. Her temperature is 38.5 C (101.3 F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. On physical examination, she has suprapubic and costovertebral angle tenderness. Urinalysis shows pyuria and bacteriuria. What is the most likely diagnosis?
 Pyelonephritis. 
The recurrent urinary tract infections, fever, and costovertebral angle tenderness are indicative of pyelonephritis.

2. A 9-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with severe left-sided abdominal pain, high fever, and vomiting for the past day. He also reports pain during urination. His mother mentions he had similar, less severe episodes over the past few months. Examination reveals tenderness in the left lumbar region. Urine analysis shows numerous leukocytes and bacteria. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 Pyelonephritis.
 His symptoms, along with the presence of leukocytes and bacteria in the urine, are indicative of a urinary tract infection that has ascended to the kidneys.

3. An 8-year-old girl is brought to the pediatrician by her father, who has noticed that she has been frequently going to the bathroom and complains of pain while urinating. She has also been having fever and pain in her lower back for the past couple of days. Physical examination reveals costovertebral angle tenderness. Urinalysis shows white blood cells and bacteria. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 Pyelonephritis. 
Her symptoms, along with the urinalysis findings, suggest a urinary tract infection that has ascended to the kidneys.

4. A 7-year-old boy presents to the clinic with a 3-day history of lower abdominal pain, fever, and vomiting. He also mentions that it hurts to urinate. Physical examination reveals tenderness in the suprapubic region and at the costovertebral angle. Urinalysis reveals pyuria and bacteriuria. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 Pyelonephritis. 
The boy's symptoms and positive urinalysis findings indicate an upper urinary tract infection.

5. A 6-year-old girl is brought to the clinic by her mother, who reports that her daughter has been having frequent, painful urination and low-grade fever for the past week. Physical examination reveals suprapubic and right costovertebral angle tenderness. Urinalysis shows pyuria and bacteriuria. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 Pyelonephritis. 
The presence of painful urination, fever, and positive urinalysis findings suggest a kidney infection.

6. A 10-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain, high fever, and vomiting. He also reports pain during urination. His medical history is significant for recurrent urinary tract infections. Examination reveals costovertebral angle tenderness. Urinalysis indicates numerous white blood cells and bacteria. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 Pyelonephritis. 
The boy's history of recurrent UTIs, current symptoms, and urinalysis findings suggest a kidney infection.

7. A 12-year-old girl presents to the clinic with a 2-day history of lower abdominal pain, frequent urination, and a fever. She also complains of a burning sensation during urination. Physical examination reveals suprapubic tenderness. Urinalysis shows pyuria and bacteriuria. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 Pyelonephritis. 
The girl's symptoms and positive urinalysis findings are indicative of an upper urinary tract infection.

8. A 4-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother, who reports that he has been having painful, frequent urination and a fever for the past few days. Physical examination reveals suprapubic and costovertebral angle tenderness. Urinalysis shows pyuria and bacteriuria. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 Pyelonephritis. 
The boy's symptoms, along with the urinalysis findings, suggest a kidney infection.

 Pyelonephritis.

column2:
1. A 4-year-old girl presents to the emergency department with her mother. She has been experiencing fever and abdominal pain for the past two days. The mother also reports that her daughter has been frequently urinating and complains of pain during urination. On physical examination, the girl appears uncomfortable and has right-sided flank tenderness. 


The answer is acute pyelonephritis due to urinary tract infection (UTI). 
The frequent urination and discomfort during urination suggest a UTI, which can ascend to the kidney causing pyelonephritis.

2. A 15-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his father with a 3-day history of fever, nausea, and right flank pain. He also complains of painful urination. He has a history of vesicoureteral reflux diagnosed in infancy. On physical examination, he has right costovertebral angle tenderness. 


The answer is vesicoureteral reflux resulting in recurrent UTIs and pyelonephritis. 
The history and symptom constellation are suggestive of pyelonephritis, likely secondary to his vesicoureteral reflux.

3. A 7-year-old girl presents to the pediatrician's office with complaints of lower abdominal pain, fever, and chills for the past two days. She also complains of a burning sensation during urination. Her mother reports that she has been drinking less water than usual. On physical examination, she appears ill and has suprapubic tenderness. 


The answer is dehydration leading to urinary stasis and pyelonephritis. 
The decreased water intake likely led to urinary stasis, facilitating bacterial growth.

4. A 10-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with fever, vomiting, and pain in the lower right side of his abdomen for the past day. He also reports painful and frequent urination. His past medical history is significant for a kidney stone at the age of 8. On physical examination, he has right-sided flank pain. 


The answer is pyelonephritis secondary to urinary stasis from past kidney stone. 
The history of a kidney stone increases the risk of UTIs and subsequent pyelonephritis.

5. A 14-year-old girl with a history of type 1 diabetes presents to the clinic with complaints of fever, nausea, and abdominal pain for the past three days. She also reports frequent urination and a burning sensation during urination. On physical examination, she has right-sided costovertebral angle tenderness. 


The answer is pyelonephritis secondary to a urinary tract infection, likely related to her diabetes. 
Diabetes increases the risk of UTIs, which can ascend to the kidneys causing pyelonephritis.

6. An 8-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of fever, abdominal pain, and frequent urination. His mother reports that he recently had a strep throat infection. On physical examination, he has right-sided flank tenderness and appears ill. 


The answer is post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis resulting in pyelonephritis. 
The recent strep throat infection combined with the current symptoms suggest a post-infectious complication of streptococcal infection.

7. A 12-year-old girl presents to the clinic with a 3-day history of fever, right-sided abdominal pain, and painful urination. She also has a history of recurrent urinary tract infections. On physical examination, she has right costovertebral angle tenderness. 


The answer is recurrent urinary tract infections leading to pyelonephritis. 
Her history of recurrent UTIs increases her risk of developing pyelonephritis.

8. A 6-year-old boy presents to the pediatrician's office with complaints of lower abdominal pain, fever, and chills for the past two days. His mother reports that he has been bedwetting for the past week. On physical examination, there is tenderness in the suprapubic region. 


The answer is pyelonephritis secondary to urinary tract infection, likely related to urinary incontinence. 
Bedwetting can lead to urinary stasis, which increases the risk of UTIs and subsequent pyelonephritis.

9. A 13-year-old girl with a history of sickle cell disease presents to the clinic with fever, nausea, and right-sided abdominal pain. She also reports frequent urination and a burning sensation during urination. On physical examination, she has right-sided costovertebral angle tenderness. 


The answer is pyelonephritis secondary to a urinary tract infection, likely related to her sickle cell disease. 
Sickle cell disease increases the risk of UTIs, which can ascend to the kidneys causing pyelonephritis.

10. A 16-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with a 1-day history of high fever, abdominal pain, and frequent urination. He also complains of pain during urination. His past medical history is significant for Hirschsprung's disease. On physical examination, he has right-sided flank pain. 


The answer is pyelonephritis secondary to urinary stasis from Hirschsprung's disease. 
The history of Hirschsprung's disease increases the risk of UTIs and subsequent pyelonephritis.

11. A 9-year-old girl presents to the clinic with a 3-day history of fever, right-sided abdominal pain, and painful urination. She also has a history of neurogenic bladder. On physical examination, she has right costovertebral angle tenderness. 


The answer is recurrent urinary tract infections leading to pyelonephritis. 
Her neurogenic bladder increases her risk of developing UTIs and pyelonephritis.

12. A 5-year-old boy presents to the pediatrician's office with complaints of lower abdominal pain, fever, and chills for the past two days. His mother reports that he was recently treated for pinworms. On physical examination, there is tenderness in the suprapubic region. 


The answer is pyelonephritis secondary to urinary tract infection, likely related to recent pinworm infection. 
Pinworms can potentially lead to bacterial contamination of the urinary tract, leading to UTI and subsequent pyelonephritis.

13. An 11-year-old boy presents to the clinic with fever, nausea, and right-sided abdominal pain. He also reports frequent urination and a burning sensation during urination. His past medical history is significant for spina bifida. On physical examination, he has right-sided costovertebral angle tenderness. 


The answer is pyelonephritis secondary to a urinary tract infection, likely related to his spina bifida. 
Spina bifida increases the risk of UTIs, which can ascend to the kidneys causing pyelonephritis.

14. A 7-year-old girl presents to the emergency department with her mother. She has been experiencing high fever and severe abdominal pain for the past day. The mother also reports that her daughter has been frequently urinating and complains of pain during urination. She has a history of posterior urethral valves. On physical examination, she appears ill and has right-sided flank tenderness. 


The answer is acute pyelonephritis due to urinary tract infection (UTI) secondary to posterior urethral valves. 
The frequent urination and discomfort during urination suggest a UTI, which could be facilitated by her underlying condition.

15. A 14-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his father with a 3-day history of fever, nausea, and right flank pain. He also complains of painful urination. He has a history of bladder exstrophy. On physical examination, he has right costovertebral angle tenderness. 


The answer is bladder exstrophy resulting in recurrent UTIs and pyelonephritis. 
The history and symptom constellation are suggestive of pyelonephritis, likely secondary to his bladder exstrophy.

16. A 6-year-old girl presents to the pediatrician's office with complaints of lower abdominal pain, fever, and chills for the past two days. She also complains of a burning sensation during urination. Her mother reports that she has been exposed to a family member with tuberculosis. On physical examination, she appears ill and has suprapubic tenderness. 


The answer is tuberculosis resulting in urinary tract infection and pyelonephritis. 
The exposure to a family member with tuberculosis combined with her current symptoms suggests a possible genitourinary tuberculosis infection.

17. A 10-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with fever, vomiting, and pain in the lower right side of his abdomen for the past day. He also reports painful and frequent urination. He recently immigrated from a developing country. On physical examination, he has right-sided flank pain. 


The answer is pyelonephritis secondary to urinary tract infection, 
possibly related to poor sanitation and hygiene practices in his home country.

18. A 12-year-old girl presents to the clinic with a 3-day history of fever, right-sided abdominal pain, and painful urination. She also has a history of polycystic kidney disease. On physical examination, she has right costovertebral angle tenderness. 


The answer is recurrent urinary tract infections leading to pyelonephritis. 
Her polycystic kidney disease increases her risk of developing UTIs and pyelonephritis.

19. A 16-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with a 1-day history of high fever, abdominal pain, and frequent urination. He also complains of pain during urination. His past medical history is significant for Duchenne muscular dystrophy. On physical examination, he has right-sided flank pain. 


The answer is pyelonephritis secondary to urinary stasis from Duchenne muscular dystrophy. 
The history of Duchenne muscular dystrophy increases the risk of UTIs and subsequent pyelonephritis.

20. A 9-year-old girl presents to the clinic with a 3-day history of fever, right-sided abdominal pain, and painful urination. She also has a history of bladder diverticulum. On physical examination, she has right costovertebral angle tenderness. 


The answer is recurrent urinary tract infections leading to pyelonephritis. 
Her bladder diverticulum increases her risk of developing UTIs and pyelonephritis.

column1: Testicular torsion or other testicular problems
column2:
1. A 16-year-old male presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe left lower quadrant pain. The pain is 8/10, sharp, and radiating to his groin. He denies any trauma, fever, or dysuria. He mentions that he was playing basketball earlier in the day. On physical exam, the left testicle is elevated and there is tenderness to palpation. A testicular ultrasound is performed and reveals absent blood flow to the left testicle. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Testicular torsion. 
Testicular torsion typically presents with acute onset of severe unilateral testicular pain, often with associated nausea and vomiting. Physical exam may reveal a high-riding testicle with horizontal lie (Bell clapper deformity).
2. A 13-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother because of a two-day history of right lower quadrant pain with associated nausea and vomiting. The boy denies any trauma, but mentions that the pain is worse when he moves. On examination, there is tenderness in the right lower quadrant with a positive Prehn's sign. Ultrasonography reveals a heterogeneous mass in the right testicle with decreased blood flow. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Testicular torsion. 
The presence of a positive Prehn's sign (relief of pain with elevation of the testicle) suggests testicular torsion. Ultrasonography with Doppler is the diagnostic modality of choice and will show decreased or absent blood flow to the affected testicle.
3. A 14-year-old boy presents to the emergency room with a one-day history of left lower quadrant pain and swelling. He mentions a recent history of trauma during a soccer game. On physical examination, the left testicle is tender, swollen, and high-riding with a horizontal lie. A testicular ultrasound shows decreased blood flow. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Testicular torsion.
The presentation of acute onset of testicular pain and swelling, especially after physical activity or trauma, is consistent with testicular torsion.
4. A 16-year-old boy comes to the emergency department complaining of severe right scrotal pain that started while he was playing basketball earlier today. He also has nausea and vomiting. On examination, the right testicle is tender, swollen and high-riding with a horizontal lie. There is loss of the cremasteric reflex on the right. An ultrasound shows decreased blood flow to the affected testicle. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Testicular torsion.
 The sudden onset of severe testicular pain with nausea and vomiting, physical findings of a high-riding testicle and absent cremasteric reflex, and ultrasound findings of decreased blood flow are all indicative of testicular torsion.
5. A 15-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with acute onset of severe left testicular pain. The pain started while he was lifting weights at the gym. On examination, the left testicle is tender, elevated, and there is loss of the cremasteric reflex on the left. An ultrasound of the scrotum shows decreased blood flow to the left testicle. What is the most likely diagnosis?
 Testicular torsion.
The sudden onset of severe testicular pain after strenuous activity like weight lifting, physical findings of a high-riding testicle and absent cremasteric reflex, and ultrasound findings of decreased blood flow are all indicative of testicular torsion.
6. A 14-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with sudden onset of right lower quadrant pain, nausea, and vomiting. He states that he was fine until he woke up this morning and felt the pain. On physical examination, the right testicle is tender, swollen, and high-riding with a horizontal lie. The cremasteric reflex is absent on the right. An ultrasound of the scrotum shows decreased blood flow to the right testicle. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Testicular torsion. 
The presentation of acute onset of testicular pain with associated nausea and vomiting, physical findings of a high-riding testicle and absent cremasteric reflex, and ultrasound findings of decreased blood flow are all indicative of testicular torsion.
7. A 17-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with a 6-hour history of severe left testicular pain. The pain woke him from sleep and is associated with nausea and vomiting. On physical examination, the left testicle is tender, swollen, and high-riding with a horizontal lie. The cremasteric reflex is absent on the left. An ultrasound of the scrotum shows decreased blood flow to the left testicle. What is the most likely diagnosis?
 Testicular torsion. 
The presentation of acute onset of testicular pain with associated nausea and vomiting, physical findings of a high-riding testicle and absent cremasteric reflex, and ultrasound findings of decreased blood flow are all indicative of testicular torsion.
8. A 12-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his father complaining of sudden left scrotal pain that started after he was hit in the groin during a football game. The pain is severe and associated with nausea and vomiting. On physical examination, the left testicle is tender, swollen, and high-riding with a horizontal lie. The cremasteric reflex is absent on the left. An ultrasound of the scrotum shows decreased blood flow to the left testicle. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Testicular torsion. 
The presentation of acute onset of testicular pain after trauma, physical findings of a high-riding testicle and absent cremasteric reflex, and ultrasound findings of decreased blood flow are all indicative of testicular torsion.
9. A 16-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with acute onset of severe right testicular pain. The pain started while he was running during a track and field practice. On physical examination, the right testicle is tender, elevated, and there is loss of the cremasteric reflex on the right. An ultrasound of the scrotum shows decreased blood flow to the right testicle. What is the most likely diagnosis?
 Testicular torsion. 
The sudden onset of severe testicular pain after strenuous activity like running, physical findings of a high-riding testicle and absent cremasteric reflex, and ultrasound findings of decreased blood flow are all indicative of testicular torsion.
10. A 13-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe left testicular pain. He also reports feeling nauseous. On physical examination, the left testicle is tender, swollen, and high-riding with a horizontal lie. The cremasteric reflex is absent on the left. An ultrasound of the scrotum shows decreased blood flow to the left testicle. What is the most likely diagnosis?
 Testicular torsion. 
The presentation of acute onset of testicular pain with associated nausea, physical findings of a high-riding testicle and absent cremasteric reflex, and ultrasound findings of decreased blood flow are all indicative of testicular torsion. 
11. A 14-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with a one-day history of right lower quadrant pain and swelling. He mentions a recent history of trauma during a wrestling match. On physical examination, the right testicle is tender, swollen, and high-riding with a horizontal lie. A testicular ultrasound shows decreased blood flow. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Testicular torsion. 
The presentation of acute onset of testicular pain and swelling, especially after physical activity or trauma, is consistent with testicular torsion.

12. A 15-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe right testicular pain. The pain started while he was doing jumping jacks in physical education class. On physical examination, the right testicle is tender, swollen, and high-riding with a horizontal lie. The cremasteric reflex is absent on the right. An ultrasound of the scrotum shows decreased blood flow to the right testicle. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Testicular torsion. 
The presentation of acute onset of testicular pain with physical activity, physical findings of a high-riding testicle and absent cremasteric reflex, and ultrasound findings of decreased blood flow are all indicative of testicular torsion.
