15. A 18-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe left testicular pain. He also reports feeling nauseous. On physical examination, the left testicle is tender, swollen, and high-riding with a horizontal lie. The cremasteric reflex is absent on the left. An ultrasound of the scrotum shows decreased blood flow to the left testicle. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Testicular torsion. 
The presentation of acute onset of testicular pain with associated nausea, physical findings of a high-riding testicle and absent cremasteric reflex, and ultrasound findings of decreased blood flow are all indicative of testicular torsion. 

16. A 13-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother because of a two-day history of right lower quadrant pain with associated nausea and vomiting. The boy denies any trauma, but mentions that the pain is worse when he moves. On examination, there is tenderness in the right lower quadrant with a positive Prehn's sign. Ultrasonography reveals a heterogeneous mass in the right testicle with decreased blood flow. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Testicular torsion. 
The presence of a positive Prehn's sign (relief of pain with elevation of the testicle) suggests testicular torsion. Ultrasonography with Doppler is the diagnostic modality of choice and will show decreased or absent blood flow to the affected testicle.

17. A 16-year-old boy comes to the emergency department complaining of severe right scrotal pain that started while he was playing basketball earlier today. He also has nausea and vomiting. On examination, the right testicle is tender, swollen and high-riding with a horizontal lie. There is loss of the cremasteric reflex on the right. An ultrasound shows decreased blood flow to the affected testicle. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Testicular torsion. 
The sudden onset of severe testicular pain with nausea and vomiting, physical findings of a high-riding testicle and absent cremasteric reflex, and ultrasound findings of decreased blood flow are all indicative of testicular torsion.

18. A 15-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with acute onset of severe left testicular pain. The pain started while he was lifting weights at the gym. On examination, the left testicle is tender, elevated, and there is loss of the cremasteric reflex on the left. An ultrasound of the scrotum shows decreased blood flow to the left testicle. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Testicular torsion. 
The sudden onset of severe testicular pain after strenuous activity like weight lifting, physical findings of a high-riding testicle and absent cremasteric reflex, and ultrasound findings of decreased blood flow are all indicative of testicular torsion.

19. A 14-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with sudden onset of right lower quadrant pain, nausea, and vomiting. He states that he was fine until he woke up this morning and felt the pain. On physical examination, the right testicle is tender, swollen, and high-riding with a horizontal lie. The cremasteric reflex is absent on the right. An ultrasound of the scrotum shows decreased blood flow to the right testicle. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Testicular torsion. 
The presentation of acute onset of testicular pain with associated nausea and vomiting, physical findings of a high-riding testicle and absent cremasteric reflex, and ultrasound findings of decreased blood flow are all indicative of testicular torsion.

20. A 17-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with a 6-hour history of severe left testicular pain. The pain woke him from sleep and is associated with nausea and vomiting. On physical examination, the left testicle is tender, swollen, and high-riding with a horizontal lie. The cremasteric reflex is absent on the left. An ultrasound of the scrotum shows decreased blood flow to the left testicle. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Testicular torsion. 
The presentation of acute onset of testicular pain with associated nausea and vomiting, physical findings of a high-riding testicle and absent cremasteric reflex, and ultrasound findings of decreased blood flow are all indicative of testicular torsion.

column1: Testicular torsion or other testicular problems
column2:
A 14-year-old boy presents to the emergency department accompanied by his mother, complaining of sudden, severe pain in his left testicle that started a few hours ago. He also mentions that he feels nauseous and vomited once at home. On physical examination, the left testicle is noticeably higher than the right and is extremely tender. The cremasteric reflex is absent on the left side. What is the most likely diagnosis?


 Testicular torsion

 The sudden onset of severe, unilateral testicular pain, associated with nausea and vomiting, and physical exam findings such as a high-riding testicle and absent cremasteric reflex, are classic signs of testicular torsion.

A 17-year-old boy comes to your office complaining of a dull ache in his right testicle for the past week. He denies any trauma or sexual activity. On physical examination, you note a 'bag of worms' appearance on the right side of the scrotum. The pain improves when he lies down. What is the most likely diagnosis?


 Varicocele

 The presence of a 'bag of worms' appearance in the scrotum and improvement of pain with recumbence are characteristic of a varicocele.

A 12-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric emergency department by his father with a complaint of severe scrotal pain that was sudden in onset and occurred while he was playing basketball. He is pale and appears in distress. The left testicle is swollen, tender, and high riding with a horizontal lie. There is a loss of the cremasteric reflex on the left side. What is the most likely diagnosis?


 Testicular torsion

 Sudden onset of severe pain, high riding testicle with a horizontal lie, and absent cremasteric reflex are classic symptoms of testicular torsion.

A 16-year-old boy presents with a 24-hour history of right-sided testicular pain. He also reports lower abdominal pain and nausea. On examination, the right testicle is tender, swollen, and high riding. The cremasteric reflex is absent on the right side. What is the most likely diagnosis?


 Testicular torsion

 The symptoms and physical findings are consistent with testicular torsion, which is a surgical emergency.

A 15-year-old boy presents to your clinic with a complaint of a painless lump in his right testicle that he discovered while taking a shower. He denies any pain, trauma, or recent illnesses. On exam, you note a hard, non-tender mass that does not transilluminate. What is the most likely diagnosis?


 Testicular cancer

 Testicular cancer often presents as a painless testicular mass that does not transilluminate. It is most common in young and middle-aged men.

A 13-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with severe left testicular pain that began suddenly while he was running in a soccer game. On examination, the left testicle is high riding and tender, with a transverse lie. The cremasteric reflex is absent. What is the most likely diagnosis?


 Testicular torsion

 The sudden onset of severe testicular pain in a young boy, along with the absence of the cremasteric reflex and a high-riding testis, is highly suggestive of testicular torsion.

A 16-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with sudden onset severe right-sided lower abdominal pain that woke him up from sleep. He also reports nausea and vomiting. On examination, the right testicle is tender and visibly swollen. The cremasteric reflex is absent on the right side. What is the most likely diagnosis?


 Testicular torsion

 The sudden onset of severe testicular pain, nausea, vomiting, swollen and tender testicle, and absent cremasteric reflex are classic signs of testicular torsion.

A 10-year-old boy presents to the clinic with his mother complaining of a lump in his testicle that he noticed a week ago. He denies any pain, trauma, or recent illnesses. On examination, there is a firm, non-tender mass in the left testicle that does not transilluminate. What is the most likely diagnosis?


 Testicular cancer

 A painless, firm, non-tender mass that does not transilluminate is strongly suggestive of testicular cancer.

A 17-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with severe left testicular pain that started suddenly while he was lifting weights. On examination, the left testicle is high riding and tender, with a horizontal lie. The cremasteric reflex is absent. What is the most likely diagnosis?


 Testicular torsion

 The sudden onset of severe testicular pain, a high riding and tender testicle with a horizontal lie, and absent cremasteric reflex are suggestive of testicular torsion.


A 15-year-old boy presents to the clinic with a dull ache in his left testicle that has been present for the past month. He denies any trauma or sexual activity. On physical examination, you note a 'bag of worms' appearance on the left side of the scrotum. What is the most likely diagnosis?


 Varicocele

 The presence of a 'bag of worms' appearance in the scrotum and a dull ache are characteristic of a varicocele.


A 16-year-old boy presents to the clinic with a dull ache and heaviness in his right testicle that has been present for the last week. He denies any trauma, fever, or recent illnesses. On examination, there is a palpable 'bag of worms' in the scrotum above the right testicle. The swelling decreases when the patient lies down. What is the most likely diagnosis?


 Varicocele

 The dull ache, heaviness, 'bag of worms' appearance, and relief on lying down are characteristic findings of a varicocele in an adolescent male.


A 14-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with his father complaining of severe left testicular pain for the past 2 hours. He also reports nausea and vomiting. On examination, the left testicle is swollen, tender, and high riding. The cremasteric reflex is absent on the left side. What is the most likely diagnosis?


 Testicular torsion

 The sudden onset of severe testicular pain, nausea, vomiting, and physical findings of a high-riding, tender, and swollen testicle with absent cremasteric reflex suggest testicular torsion.


A 12-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother with sudden, severe left testicular pain that began while he was playing soccer. On examination, the left testicle is tender, swollen, and high riding. The cremasteric reflex is absent on the left side. What is the most likely diagnosis?


 Testicular torsion

 The sudden onset of severe testicular pain, especially during physical activity, along with findings of a high-riding, tender, and swollen testicle and absent cremasteric reflex, are suggestive of testicular torsion.


A 13-year-old boy presents to the clinic with a 2-day history of mild, right testicular pain. He denies trauma or urinary symptoms. On examination, the right testicle is slightly tender and swollen. Urinalysis is positive for leukocytes and bacteria. What is the most likely diagnosis?


 Epididymitis

 In contrast to testicular torsion, epididymitis usually presents with gradual onset of scrotal pain and is associated with urinary symptoms or infection.


A 15-year-old boy presents to your clinic with a complaint of a painless lump in his left testicle that he discovered while taking a shower. He denies any pain, trauma, or recent illnesses. On exam, you note a hard, non-tender mass that does not transilluminate. What is the most likely diagnosis?


 Testicular cancer

 Testicular cancer often presents as a painless testicular mass that does not transilluminate. It is most common in young and middle-aged men.


A 14-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother with a complaint of sudden, severe right lower abdominal pain that radiates to the groin. He appears pale and diaphoretic. On examination, the right testicle is swollen, tender, and high riding. The cremasteric reflex is absent on the right side. What is the most likely diagnosis?


 Testicular torsion

 The sudden onset of severe testicular pain, along with a high-riding, tender, and swollen testicle and absent cremasteric reflex, are classic signs of testicular torsion.


An 18-year-old boy presents to the clinic with a 6-month history of a painless lump in his right testicle. He denies any trauma or recent illness but admits to weight loss, fatigue, and a low-grade fever. On physical examination, you note a firm, non-tender mass in the right testicle that does not transilluminate. What is the most likely diagnosis?


 Testicular cancer

 Painless testicular mass associated with systemic symptoms like weight loss, fatigue, and low-grade fever in a young male suggests testicular cancer.


A 12-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric emergency department by his father with a complaint of sudden, severe right testicular pain that started while he was at school. He is in obvious distress and appears pale. On examination, the right testicle is swollen, tender, and high riding. The cremasteric reflex is absent on the right side. What is the most likely diagnosis?


 Testicular torsion

 The sudden onset of severe testicular pain, along with a high-riding, tender, and swollen testicle and absent cremasteric reflex, are classic signs of testicular torsion.


A 17-year-old boy presents to the clinic with a 6-month history of a painless lump in his left testicle. He denies any trauma or recent illness. On physical examination, you note a firm, non-tender mass in the left testicle that does not transilluminate. What is the most likely diagnosis?


 Testicular cancer

 Painless testicular mass that is firm, non-tender, and does not transilluminate suggests the likelihood of testicular cancer.


A 16-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with his father, complaining of sudden, severe pain in his left testicle that started a few hours ago while playing football. He also mentions that he feels nauseous. On physical examination, the left testicle is noticeably higher than the right and is extremely tender. The cremasteric reflex is absent on the left side. What is the most likely diagnosis?


 Testicular torsion

 The sudden onset of severe, unilateral testicular pain, associated with nausea, and physical exam findings such as a high-riding testicle and absent cremasteric reflex, are classic signs of testicular torsion.

column53: Painless testicular mass associated with systemic symptoms like weight loss, fatigue, and low-grade fever in a young male suggests testicular cancer.
column54: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric emergency department by his father with a complaint of sudden, severe right testicular pain that started while he was at school. He is in obvious distress and appears pale. On examination, the right testicle is swollen, tender, and high riding. The cremasteric reflex is absent on the right side. What is the most likely diagnosis?
column56: The sudden onset of severe testicular pain, along with a high-riding, tender, and swollen testicle and absent cremasteric reflex, are classic signs of testicular torsion.
column57: A 17-year-old boy presents to the clinic with a 6-month history of a painless lump in his left testicle. He denies any trauma or recent illness. On physical examination, you note a firm, non-tender mass in the left testicle that does not transilluminate. What is the most likely diagnosis?
column59: Painless testicular mass that is firm, non-tender, and does not transilluminate suggests the likelihood of testicular cancer.
column60: A 16-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with his father, complaining of sudden, severe pain in his left testicle that started a few hours ago while playing football. What is the most likely diagnosis?
column62: The sudden onset of severe, unilateral testicular pain, associated with nausea, and physical exam findings such as a high-riding testicle and absent cremasteric reflex, are classic signs of testicular torsion.

column1: Testicular torsion or other testicular problems
column2:
1. A 14-year-old Caucasian male is brought to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe left-sided abdominal pain. He reports that he was playing soccer when he fell down and started experiencing the pain. On examination, his left testicle is swollen, tender, and high-riding with a horizontal lie. The cremasteric reflex is absent on the left side. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 Testicular torsion.

 The sudden onset of severe pain, high-riding testicle, absent cremasteric reflex, and testicular swelling are classic signs of testicular torsion. This condition is a urologic emergency that requires immediate surgical intervention to save the testicle.

2. A 16-year-old African American boy presents to the clinic with a 2-day history of right lower quadrant pain that radiates to the groin. He denies any trauma or physical activity before the pain started. On examination, his right testicle is swollen and tender. The pain is relieved by lifting the testicle. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 Epididymitis.

 This patient's presentation is consistent with epididymitis, which can mimic testicular torsion. The key distinguishing feature here is the relief of pain with elevation of the testicle (Prehn's sign), which is suggestive of epididymitis, not torsion.

3. A 13-year-old Hispanic boy is brought to the emergency department with severe, sudden-onset pain in his right testicle that started 6 hours ago. He denies any trauma or physical activity. column1: Testicular torsion or other testicular problems
column2:
1. A 13-year-old boy presents to the ER with his mother, complaining of sudden onset, severe pain in his right testicle. The pain started two hours ago while he was playing soccer. He also complains of nausea. On physical examination, the right testicle is swollen, tender, and high-riding with a horizontal lie. The cremasteric reflex is absent on the right side. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 Testicular torsion

 The sudden onset of severe, unilateral testicular pain, associated with nausea, high-riding and horizontally lying testicles, and absence of the cremasteric reflex suggests testicular torsion. 

2. A 14-year-old boy comes to the emergency department with sudden onset, severe left testicular pain. He says that the pain started a few hours ago while he was lifting weights at the gym. On examination, the left testicle is tender, swollen, and high-riding with a horizontal lie. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 Testicular torsion

 The patient's symptoms and signs are highly suggestive of testicular torsion. 

3. A 12-year-old boy presents to the ER with acute abdominal pain that began 6 hours ago. On physical examination, there is slight tenderness in the lower abdomen, but the boy also complains of severe pain in his right testicle. The right testicle is swollen, tender, and high-riding with a horizontal lie. The cremasteric reflex is absent on the right side. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 Testicular torsion

 Testicular torsion often presents with abdominal pain and nausea, in addition to severe testicular pain. The absence of the cremasteric reflex is a strong indicator of testicular torsion.

4. A 16-year-old boy is brought to the ER by his mother, complaining of severe, sudden onset of pain in his left testicle that started while he was playing football. Examination reveals a high-riding, tender, and swollen left testicle with a horizontal lie. The cremasteric reflex is absent on the left side. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 Testicular torsion

 The sudden onset of severe unilateral testicular pain, especially in a boy in his early teens, is a classic presentation of testicular torsion. 

5. A 15-year-old boy presents with severe pain in his right testicle. The pain started suddenly at night while he was sleeping and woke him up. On examination, the right testicle is swollen, tender, and high-riding with a horizontal lie. The cremasteric reflex is absent on the right side. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 Testicular torsion

 Testicular torsion can occur at any time, even during sleep. The signs and symptoms mentioned are typical of testicular torsion.

column1: Testicular torsion or other testicular problems
column2:
1. A 14-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with acute severe right lower quadrant abdominal pain that started suddenly during a basketball game at school. He is doubled over in pain and is nauseated but has not vomited. His mother reports he has no medical history and takes no medications. Physical examination reveals a high-riding right testicle that is tender to touch. The cremasteric reflex is absent on the right side. What is the most likely diagnosis?


 Testicular torsion.

 The acute onset of severe testicular pain, associated with symptoms such as nausea and the physical examination findings of an absent cremasteric reflex and high-riding testicle, are classic for testicular torsion.

2. A 12-year-old boy presents to your office with his father. The boy complains of lower abdominal pain and testicular discomfort that started a week ago. The pain is dull and aching in nature. He denies any trauma or physical exertion. On examination, you note a swollen, tender right testicle. The cremasteric reflex is present and the pain is relieved by lifting the testicle (Prehn's sign). What is the most likely diagnosis?


 Epididymitis.

 The symptoms, timing, and positive Prehn's sign point to epididymitis, which is an inflammation of the epididymis often caused by a bacterial infection.

3. A 16-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of right-sided abdominal pain that radiates to the groin. He also complains of nausea and vomiting. His past medical history is unremarkable. Physical examination reveals a tender right testicle that is high-riding and horizontally positioned. The right cremasteric reflex is absent. What is the most likely diagnosis?


 Testicular torsion.

 The sudden onset of abdominal pain, associated nausea and vomiting, and physical examination findings suggest testicular torsion.

4. A 13-year-old boy presents with abdominal pain, fever, and malaise for the past 24 hours. He also complains of testicular discomfort. On exam, his right testicle is tender and swollen. The pain is relieved with elevation (positive Prehn's sign) and the cremasteric reflex is present. What is the most likely diagnosis?


 Epididymitis.

 The presentation of abdominal pain, fever, and malaise, along with a tender and swollen testicle that is relieved with elevation, suggests epididymitis.

5. A 17-year-old boy presents with severe right-sided abdominal pain that started suddenly during a soccer game. He also reports feeling nauseous. Physical examination reveals a high-riding, tender right testicle. The cremasteric reflex is absent on the right side. What is the most likely diagnosis?


 Testicular torsion.

 The acute onset of severe testicular pain, associated symptoms of nausea, and physical examination findings are classic for testicular torsion.

6. An 11-year-old boy presents to your office with his mother, complaining of lower abdominal pain and right testicular discomfort for the past two days. On examination, his right testicle is tender and swollen. The pain is relieved with elevation, and the cremasteric reflex is present. What is the most likely diagnosis?


 Epididymitis.

 The presentation of lower abdominal pain and testicular discomfort, along with physical examination findings, suggests epididymitis.

7. A 15-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain that started suddenly during a wrestling match. He is pale and sweating profusely. On physical examination, his right testicle is high-riding, painful, and has a transverse lie. The right cremasteric reflex is absent. What is the most likely diagnosis?


 Testicular torsion.

 Epididymitis.

column1: Testicular torsion or other testicular problems
column2:
A 14-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with severe right lower quadrant abdominal pain that started suddenly about 4 hours ago. The pain is constant and does not radiate elsewhere. The boy is nauseous and has vomited twice. He denies any urinary or bowel complaints. On physical examination, the patient appears uncomfortable and is guarding his right lower quadrant. A testicular examination reveals an exquisitely tender, high-riding right testis with a horizontal lie. 
This patient's presentation is suggestive of testicular torsion.  
Testicular torsion typically presents with sudden onset of severe testicular pain that may also be associated with lower abdominal pain. The high-riding testis with a horizontal lie (Bell-Clapper deformity) is pathognomonic.
A 12-year-old boy has been experiencing intermittent lower abdominal pain for the past week. The pain is severe, sudden in onset, and associated with nausea and vomiting. He also complains of discomfort in the right lower quadrant of his abdomen. Physical examination reveals tenderness in the right lower quadrant of his abdomen. On scrotal examination, the right testis is found to be swollen, tender, and high-riding with a horizontal lie. 
The patient's symptoms are suggestive of intermittent testicular torsion. 
Intermittent torsion and detorsion can present with episodes of severe pain that resolve spontaneously as the testis untwists. However, the high-riding testis and horizontal lie suggest that the torsion is currently present.
A 16-year-old boy with a history of undescended testes repaired at 1 year of age presents with severe left lower quadrant pain that started 2 hours ago. Physical examination reveals tenderness in the left lower quadrant and a high-riding left testis with a horizontal lie. The patient also reports nausea and has vomited once. 
The patient's symptoms suggest testicular torsion. 
Patients with a history of undescended testes are at increased risk for testicular torsion. The high-riding testis and horizontal lie are characteristic findings.
A 15-year-old boy presents with a 3-day history of right lower quadrant pain associated with nausea and vomiting. He also reports a recent upper respiratory tract infection. On examination, there is tenderness in the right lower quadrant and his right testis is swollen and tender, but not high-riding or lying horizontally. 
This patient's presentation is suggestive of epididymitis. 
Epididymitis often presents with gradual onset of scrotal pain and is associated with urinary symptoms or recent infection. The absence of a high-riding testis or horizontal lie makes torsion less likely.
A 13-year-old boy presents with severe right testicular pain that started suddenly 6 hours ago. The pain is associated with nausea and vomiting. On physical examination, the right testis is high-riding with a horizontal lie.
This patient's presentation suggests testicular torsion. 
The sudden onset of severe testicular pain with a high-riding testis and horizontal lie is characteristic of testicular torsion.

column14: Epididymitis often presents with gradual onset of scrotal pain and is associated with urinary symptoms or recent infection. The absence of a high-riding testis or horizontal lie makes torsion less likely.
column15: A 13-year-old boy presents with severe right testicular pain that started suddenly 6 hours ago. The pain is associated with nausea and vomiting. On physical examination, the right testis is high-riding with a horizontal lie.
column16: This patient's presentation suggests testicular torsion.
column17: The sudden onset of severe testicular pain with a high-riding testis and horizontal lie is characteristic of testicular torsion.

column2:
A 13-year-old girl is brought to the clinic by her mother due to severe abdominal pain. The pain started a few hours ago and is constant, crampy, and located in the lower abdomen. She has never experienced this before. She denies any vomiting, diarrhea, or fever. She had her first menstrual period a year ago and reports that her cycles have been regular. She mentions that her current menses started this morning. On physical examination, her vital signs are within normal limits. The abdomen is soft, but there is tenderness in the lower quadrants. Pelvic examination is declined by the patient. 


 Primary Dysmenorrhoea

 Primary dysmenorrhoea typically begins during adolescence, within a few years of menarche, once ovulatory cycles are established. Pain usually begins at the onset of menses and lasts less than 72 hours. 

A 15-year-old female comes to the clinic with her mother complaining of severe abdominal pain that began yesterday. She describes it as a cramping pain in her lower abdomen that is most severe on the first day of her menstrual cycle. She also reports nausea and fatigue. Her menstrual cycles have been regular since menarche at 12 years old. Physical examination is unremarkable except for tenderness to palpation in the lower abdomen.


 Primary Dysmenorrhoea

 The presentation is typical of primary dysmenorrhoea, which begins with the onset of ovulatory cycles, often within the first few years after menarche.

A 12-year-old female is brought to the pediatrician by her mother due to severe abdominal pain that started this morning. The pain is crampy, located in the lower abdomen, and associated with nausea. The patient reports that her menses began yesterday. On examination, the abdomen is soft with tenderness in the lower quadrants. No masses or organomegaly are palpable.


 Primary Dysmenorrhoea

 This is a typical presentation of primary dysmenorrhoea, which is characterized by lower abdominal cramping pain that starts shortly before or at the onset of menses and lasts for several days.

A 14-year-old girl presents to the pediatrician with complaints of severe abdominal pain that started today. She describes the pain as crampy and located in the lower abdomen. She also reports feeling nauseous and lightheaded. Her menses started yesterday. Physical examination shows tenderness in the lower abdominal quadrants. 


 Primary Dysmenorrhoea

 Primary dysmenorrhoea typically starts with the onset of ovulatory cycles, often within the first few years after menarche. The pain is usually most severe on the first day of the menstrual cycle.

A 16-year-old female presents to the clinic with her mother complaining of severe recurrent abdominal pain for the past six months. She describes the pain as crampy and located in the lower abdomen. The pain typically starts a few hours before her menses and lasts for about 2-3 days. She denies any other symptoms. Physical examination reveals tenderness in the lower abdominal quadrants. 


 Primary Dysmenorrhoea

 Dysmenorrhoea is the most common gynecologic complaint among adolescent females. It is characterized by crampy pelvic pain that begins shortly before or at the onset of menses and lasts for several days.

column2:
1. A 14-year-old girl presents to the clinic with a complaint of severe lower abdominal pain that occurs every month around her menstrual cycle. She describes the pain as cramping, and it often causes her to miss school. The pain is typically associated with her periods and usually lasts for 2-3 days. Physical examination is unremarkable. 
The most likely diagnosis is primary dysmenorrhoea. 
Primary dysmenorrhoea is common in adolescents and often begins 6-12 months after menarche, when ovulatory cycles are established.

2. A 15-year-old girl is brought to the clinic by her mother due to recurrent abdominal pain. The patient reports that the pain is usually severe, starts with the onset of her menses, and lasts for 3-4 days. She has had regular periods for the last two years. Her mother mentions a similar history during her adolescence. The physical examination is normal. 

The likely diagnosis is primary dysmenorrhoea, a condition that can often have a genetic predisposition.

3. A 16-year-old girl comes to the clinic with a history of severe abdominal pain during her periods. She is an active athlete and reports that the pain often disrupts her training. She has tried over-the-counter pain relievers, but they provide minimal relief. On physical examination, there are no alarming signs. 
The probable diagnosis is primary dysmenorrhoea. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) are often effective for pain relief but may need to be prescribed at higher doses.

4. A 13-year-old girl presents to the clinic for a routine check-up. During the examination, she mentions that she has been experiencing severe lower abdominal pain that starts with her periods and lasts for a couple of days. She also reports that she often feels nauseous and sometimes vomits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The diagnosis is primary dysmenorrhoea, which can sometimes present with nausea and vomiting due to the release of prostaglandins in the uterus.

5. A 15-year-old girl comes to the clinic with her mother, complaining of severe pain during her periods. She also reports heavy bleeding and passing clots. She mentions that the pain often causes her to miss school. The physical examination is normal. The diagnosis is likely primary dysmenorrhoea with menorrhagia. Both conditions are common in adolescence and can often coexist.

6. A 16-year-old girl presents to the clinic with a history of severe abdominal pain during her periods. She is sexually active and uses condoms for contraception. She denies any abnormal vaginal discharge or pain during intercourse. Physical examination is normal. The diagnosis is primary dysmenorrhoea. Despite being sexually active, the patient's history and physical examination do not suggest a sexually transmitted infection or pelvic inflammatory disease.

7. A 14-year-old girl brought to the clinic by her mother complaining of severe lower abdominal pain that starts with her periods and lasts for a few days. She also reports that she often feels lightheaded and has fainted once during her period. The physical examination is normal. The diagnosis is primary dysmenorrhoea. The fainting and lightheadedness are likely due to vasovagal syncope, a common reaction to pain.

8. A 15-year-old girl presents to the clinic with a history of severe lower abdominal pain during her periods. The pain is often so severe that she cannot participate in her usual activities. She also reports that the pain is often accompanied by diarrhea. The physical examination is normal. The diagnosis is primary dysmenorrhoea. The diarrhea is likely due to the release of prostaglandins in the uterus, which can also affect the gastrointestinal tract.

9. A 13-year-old girl is brought to the clinic by her mother, who is concerned about her daughter's severe lower abdominal pain during her periods. The patient reports that the pain often wakes her up at night and is not relieved by over-the-counter pain relievers. The physical examination is normal. The diagnosis is primary dysmenorrhoea. This condition can often disrupt sleep, especially when the pain is severe.

10. A 16-year-old girl presents to the clinic with a complaint of severe lower abdominal pain during her periods. She also reports that she often feels bloated and constipated before her periods. The physical examination is normal. The diagnosis is primary dysmenorrhoea with premenstrual syndrome (PMS). Both conditions are common in adolescents and can often coexist.

11. A 15-year-old girl comes to the clinic with a complaint of severe lower abdominal pain during her periods. She mentions that the pain often starts a day before her periods and lasts for the first two days of her cycle. The physical examination is normal. The diagnosis is primary dysmenorrhoea. This condition can often start before the onset of menses, especially when the pain is severe.

12. A 14-year-old girl presents to the clinic with a history of severe lower abdominal pain during her periods. She also mentions that she often feels tired and irritable before her periods. The physical examination is normal. The diagnosis is primary dysmenorrhoea with premenstrual syndrome (PMS). Both conditions often coexist and can cause significant distress in adolescents.

13. A 13-year-old girl is brought to the clinic by her mother, who is concerned about her daughter's severe lower abdominal pain during her periods. The patient reports that the pain usually starts with her periods and lasts for a few days. She also mentions that she often feels anxious and has difficulty concentrating at school during her periods. The physical examination is normal. The diagnosis is primary dysmenorrhoea with premenstrual dysphoric disorder (PMDD). PMDD is a severe form of PMS and can often coexist with dysmenorrhoea.

14. A 16-year-old girl presents to the clinic with a complaint of severe lower abdominal pain during her periods. She also reports that she often feels bloated and has headaches before her periods. The physical examination is normal. The diagnosis is primary dysmenorrhoea with premenstrual syndrome (PMS). Both conditions are common in adolescents and can often coexist.

15. A 15-year-old girl comes to the clinic with a complaint of severe lower abdominal pain during her periods. She mentions that the pain is usually so severe that she cannot participate in her usual activities. She also reports that she often has mood swings and feels depressed before her periods. The physical examination is normal. The diagnosis is primary dysmenorrhoea with premenstrual dysphoric disorder (PMDD). PMDD is a severe form of PMS and can often coexist with dysmenorrhoea.

16. A 14-year-old girl presents to the clinic with a history of severe lower abdominal pain during her periods. She also reports that she often has difficulty sleeping and feels anxious before her periods. The physical examination is normal. The diagnosis is primary dysmenorrhoea with premenstrual dysphoric disorder (PMDD). PMDD is a severe form of PMS and can often coexist with dysmenorrhoea.

column2:
1) A 14-year-old girl presents with severe abdominal pain that started a few hours ago. She describes the pain as crampy and severe, located mainly in the lower abdomen. Her mother states that the girl started menstruating a year ago, and that her periods have been irregular and often accompanied by similar episodes of pain. Vital signs are stable and physical exam reveals tenderness in the lower abdomen with no rebound or guarding. 


 The most likely diagnosis is primary dysmenorrhoea. Painful menstruation is common in the first few years after menarche, especially with irregular periods. 

2) A 16-year-old girl presents with severe, crampy lower abdominal pain that started yesterday. She says that her last period started three days ago and that she often experiences similar pain during her period. She also mentions that she has been feeling nauseated. On physical exam, the lower abdomen is tender to palpation but there are no signs of peritoneal irritation. 


 The patient's symptoms are consistent with menstrual pain (dysmenorrhoea). The nausea can be a part of the systemic symptoms that accompany menstruation in some women.

3) A 12-year-old girl is brought in by her mother for lower abdominal pain that started this morning. The mother reports that the girl started her period six months ago and that she has had similar episodes of pain with each period. On physical exam, there is lower abdominal tenderness. 


 This patient is experiencing primary dysmenorrhoea, which is common in young girls after menarche.

4) A 15-year-old girl presents with severe lower abdominal pain that started suddenly yesterday. She states her last period ended a week ago and she has never experienced this type of pain before. On physical exam, there is diffuse abdominal tenderness. 


 Although the timing is unusual, this could be a severe case of dysmenorrhoea. However, the sudden onset and severity of symptoms warrant further investigation to rule out other causes of acute abdominal pain.

5) A 17-year-old girl presents with severe, crampy lower abdominal pain that began yesterday. She reports that her periods have always been painful, but this is much worse than usual. She also notes that she has been feeling lightheaded. On physical exam, there is lower abdominal tenderness. 


 This case is suggestive of severe dysmenorrhoea, possibly complicated by anemia due to heavy menstrual bleeding. The lightheadedness could be a symptom of the anemia.

6) A 13-year-old girl comes in with her mother, complaining of severe lower abdominal pain that started this morning. The mother mentions that the girl started her period yesterday. On physical examination, there is tenderness in the lower abdomen.


 The girl's symptoms are consistent with primary dysmenorrhoea, which is common after menarche.

7) A 15-year-old girl presents with severe, crampy lower abdominal pain that started a few hours ago. She states her last period ended two weeks ago and she has never experienced this type of pain before. On physical exam, there is lower abdominal tenderness.


 Although the timing is unusual, this could be a case of dysmenorrhoea. However, further investigation is needed to rule out other causes of abdominal pain.

8) A 16-year-old girl presents with severe, crampy lower abdominal pain that started yesterday. She reports that her periods have always been painful, but this is much worse than usual. She also mentions that she has been feeling nauseated and faint. On physical exam, there is lower abdominal tenderness.


 This could be a severe case of dysmenorrhoea. However, the fainting and nausea may suggest an associated condition, such as anemia or endometriosis.

9) A 14-year-old girl is brought in by her mother for lower abdominal pain that started this morning. The mother reports that the girl started her period two days ago and that she has had similar episodes of pain with each period. On physical exam, there is lower abdominal tenderness.

column2:
1. A 14-year-old girl presents to the emergency room with severe lower abdominal pain. The pain started a few hours ago and is accompanied by nausea and vomiting. The patient reports that the pain is similar to menstrual cramps but more intense. Her last menstrual period started two days ago. Examination reveals a tender lower abdomen with no rebound tenderness or rigidity. 



The answer is primary dysmenorrhoea. The patient's symptoms started with the onset of her menstrual period and the pain is similar to menstrual cramps.

2. A 12-year-old girl presents to the doctor's office with complaints of lower abdominal pain that started yesterday. The pain is cramping in nature and is associated with her menstrual period, which started yesterday. She also reports feeling nauseous. Physical examination reveals normal vital signs and tenderness in the lower abdomen. 



The answer is primary dysmenorrhoea, which is characterized by menstrual pain without an identifiable pelvic pathology.

column2:
1. A 13-year-old girl presents to your office with complaints of lower abdominal pain for the past 6 months. The pain usually starts a day before her menstrual period and lasts for 2-3 days. She describes the pain as a cramping sensation. She also mentions that she sometimes feels nauseated and even vomited once during the pain. Her periods are regular and she denies any sexual activity. Physical examination is unremarkable with no signs of acute abdomen. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 Primary Dysmenorrhoea

 The onset of pain associated with menstruation and absence of pelvic pathology on physical examination is suggestive of primary dysmenorrhoea.

2. A 15-year-old girl visits your clinic with her mother who reports that her daughter has been missing school for the past few months due to severe lower abdominal pain. The pain occurs every month, usually at the start of her menstrual cycle, and lasts for about two days. The girl describes the pain as severe, crampy, and occasionally accompanied by vomiting. Physical exam and ultrasound are unremarkable. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 Primary Dysmenorrhoea

 The cyclic nature of the pain, which is severe enough to affect daily activities, along with a normal physical examination and ultrasound, suggest primary dysmenorrhoea.

3. A 16-year-old adolescent girl presents to the emergency department with severe lower abdominal pain that started this morning. She describes the pain as sharp and crampy, radiating to her lower back. She reports that her menses started yesterday, and she usually has painful periods. Her last menstrual period was 28 days ago, and she denies any sexual activity. On physical examination, no abnormalities are found. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 Primary Dysmenorrhoea

 The timing of pain, its association with menses, and the absence of any abnormal findings on physical examination suggest primary dysmenorrhoea.

4. A 14-year-old girl presents to the outpatient clinic with a 6-month history of painful periods. The pain usually starts a day before the menses and lasts for the first two days of menstruation. She describes the pain as a cramping sensation that radiates to the lower back. She also reports occasional nausea and vomiting. The physical examination is unremarkable. What is the most probable diagnosis?

 Primary Dysmenorrhoea

 The timing of the pain, its association with menses, and the absence of any abnormal findings on physical examination suggest primary dysmenorrhoea.

5. A 17-year-old girl presents to your office complaining of severe lower abdominal pain that starts with her periods and lasts for the first two days. She also reports nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea during these episodes. Her periods are regular, and she is not sexually active. On physical examination, there are no signs of acute abdomen. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 Primary Dysmenorrhoea

 The timing of the pain, its association with menses, the presence of gastrointestinal symptoms, and the absence of any abnormal findings on physical examination suggest primary dysmenorrhoea.

6. A 12-year-old girl presents to your clinic with her mother. She is complaining of severe lower abdominal pain that usually starts a day before her menstrual cycle and lasts for about 2-3 days. She describes the pain as crampy and is often accompanied by nausea and vomiting. Her periods are regular with a cycle length of 28 days. She denies sexual activity. On examination, there are no signs of acute abdomen. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 Primary Dysmenorrhoea

 The timing of the pain, its association with menses, and the absence of any abnormal findings on physical examination suggest primary dysmenorrhoea.

7. A 15-year-old girl presents to your office complaining of severe lower abdominal pain that starts with her periods and lasts for about 2 days. She describes the pain as a cramping sensation that is often associated with nausea and vomiting. Her periods are regular, and she is not sexually active. On examination, the abdomen is soft and non-tender. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 Primary Dysmenorrhoea

 The timing of the pain, its association with menses, and the absence of any abnormal findings on physical examination suggest primary dysmenorrhoea.

She also reports occasional nausea and vomiting. The physical examination is unremarkable. What is the most probable diagnosis?
column14: The timing of the pain, its association with menses, and the absence of any abnormal findings on physical examination suggest primary dysmenorrhoea.
column15: 5. A 17-year-old girl presents to your office complaining of severe lower abdominal pain that starts with her periods and lasts for the first two days. She also reports nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea during these episodes. Her periods are regular, and she is not sexually active. On physical examination, there are no signs of acute abdomen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
column17: The timing of the pain, its association with menses, the presence of gastrointestinal symptoms, and the absence of any abnormal findings on physical examination suggest primary dysmenorrhoea.

On examination, there are no signs of acute abdomen. What is the most likely diagnosis?

column2:
1. A 14-year-old girl presents with a two-day history of lower abdominal pain. She says the pain is cramp-like and has been getting worse. She also mentions that she started her period two days ago, which is her third period since menarche. She feels nauseated and has been experiencing bouts of diarrhea. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Examination reveals mild tenderness in the lower abdomen without rebound. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 Menstrual pain (dysmenorrhoea).

 Dysmenorrhoea is common in young females and often begins with the onset of ovulatory cycles. The pain is usually cramp-like and is associated with nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea.

2. A 16-year-old girl comes to the clinic due to severe pain in her lower abdomen that started today. She rates the pain as 8/10. She says that she usually has some pain with her periods, but this is much worse. She also reports heavy menstrual bleeding. She has no fever, and her vitals are stable. On examination, her lower abdomen is tender to palpation without rebound or guarding. What is the most probable diagnosis?

 Menstrual pain (dysmenorrhoea).

 The clinical history and physical examination findings are suggestive of severe dysmenorrhoea. The heavy menstrual bleeding can be a feature of menorrhagia, which can coexist with dysmenorrhoea.

3. A 13-year-old girl presents with lower abdominal pain and vomiting. She describes the pain as sharp and crampy, starting yesterday, which was the first day of her menstrual cycle. She denies any fever, chills, or urinary symptoms but reports feeling lightheaded. Her mother mentions that she started menstruating at age 12 and her cycles have been regular since then. Examination reveals a tender lower abdomen without rebound or guarding. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 Menstrual pain (dysmenorrhoea).

 Dysmenorrhoea is common in girls after menarche and tends to be most severe on the first day of the menstrual cycle. The nausea and lightheadedness can be associated symptoms.

4. A 15-year-old girl comes to the clinic with a two-day history of lower abdominal pain. She rates the pain as 7/10, saying it's crampy and comes in waves. She started her period two days ago, and the pain began around the same time. She also has occasional vomiting. On examination, her abdomen is tender in the lower quadrants without rebound or guarding. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 Menstrual pain (dysmenorrhoea).

 Dysmenorrhoea, which often begins with the onset of menstrual bleeding, typically presents as crampy lower abdominal pain. Nausea and vomiting can be associated symptoms.

5. An 11-year-old girl presents with lower abdominal pain that started this morning. She says the pain is "like a cramp" and is associated with nausea. Her mother reports that the patient had her first menstrual period this morning. On examination, the patient appears uncomfortable and her lower abdomen is mildly tender on palpation. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 Menstrual pain (dysmenorrhoea).

 Dysmenorrhoea is common in girls after menarche and often begins with the onset of menstrual bleeding. The pain is usually cramp-like and is associated with nausea.

6. A 17-year-old girl presents with severe lower abdominal pain that started yesterday. She rates the pain as 9/10 and says it's the worst pain she's ever felt. She started menstruating at age 11 and her cycles have been regular. She reports that she usually has some pain with her periods, but this is much worse. Examination reveals a tender lower abdomen without rebound or guarding. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 Menstrual pain (dysmenorrhoea).

 Dysmenorrhoea can be severe and is often worse with the onset of menstrual bleeding. The fact that the patient has experienced milder dysmenorrhoea in the past supports this diagnosis.

7. A 14-year-old girl presents with a one-day history of lower abdominal pain. She says the pain is cramp-like and started on the first day of her menstrual period. She also reports feeling nauseated. On examination, her lower abdomen is tender to palpation. Her vital signs are within normal limits. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 Menstrual pain (dysmenorrhoea).

 Dysmenorrhoea is common in adolescents and often begins with the onset of menstrual bleeding. The pain is usually cramp-like and is associated with nausea.

8. A 16-year-old girl presents with lower abdominal pain that started this morning. She describes the pain as sharp and crampy. She also reports starting her period this morning. On examination, her lower abdomen is tender to palpation without rebound or guarding. Her vital signs are within normal limits. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 Menstrual pain (dysmenorrhoea).

 Dysmenorrhoea typically presents as crampy lower abdominal pain that begins with the onset of menstrual bleeding.

9. A 12-year-old girl presents with severe lower abdominal pain that started last night. She describes the pain as "like a cramp" and says it is associated with nausea and vomiting. She started her period last night, which is her first period since menarche. On examination, her lower abdomen is tender to palpation without rebound or guarding. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 Menstrual pain (dysmenorrhoea).

 Dysmenorrhoea is common after menarche and often begins with the onset of menstrual bleeding. The pain is usually cramp-like and is associated with nausea and vomiting.

10. A 15-year-old girl presents with lower abdominal pain that started two days ago. She rates the pain as 7/10 and says it's been getting worse. She also reports that she started her period two days ago. On examination, her lower abdomen is tender to palpation without rebound or guarding. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 Menstrual pain (dysmenorrhoea).

 Dysmenorrhoea often begins with the onset of menstrual bleeding and can increase in severity over the first few days of the menstrual cycle.

11. A 13-year-old girl presents with a two-day history of lower abdominal pain. She rates the pain as 6/10 and says it feels like a "cramp". She also reports starting her period two days ago. On examination, her lower abdomen is mildly tender to palpation without rebound or guarding. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 Menstrual pain (dysmenorrhoea).

 Dysmenorrhoea often begins with the onset of menstrual bleeding and typically presents as crampy lower abdominal pain.

She also reports heavy menstrual bleeding. On examination, her lower abdomen is tender to palpation without rebound or guarding. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 The clinical history and physical examination findings are suggestive of severe dysmenorrhoea. The heavy menstrual bleeding can be a feature of menorrhagia, which can coexist with dysmenorrhoea.

column2:
A 14-year-old girl presents to the emergency department with sudden severe lower right abdominal pain. She describes it as sharp and constant. She also notes some nausea but denies vomiting, fever, or changes in bowel habits. Her last menstrual period was two weeks ago and was normal. On physical examination, she is in obvious distress and has severe tenderness in the right lower quadrant with voluntary guarding. 
The patient's symptoms are suggestive of ovarian cyst torsion. 
This condition often presents with sudden onset of severe unilateral lower abdominal pain. In this patient, the lack of systemic symptoms such as fever or changes in bowel habits makes other diagnoses like appendicitis less likely. 
A 12-year-old girl presents to the clinic with a 1-day history of lower left abdominal pain. The pain is dull and intermittent. She also reports mild nausea but no vomiting. She does not report any changes in bowel or bladder habits. Her last menstrual period was three weeks ago and was normal. On physical examination, she is comfortable and has mild tenderness in the left lower quadrant.  
This patient's symptoms are suggestive of an ovarian cyst. 
Ovarian cysts can be asymptomatic but may cause dull, unilateral lower abdominal pain. The intermittent nature of the pain and the lack of associated symptoms make this diagnosis more likely in this patient. 
A 15-year-old girl presents to the emergency department with severe lower abdominal pain that started suddenly about 6 hours ago. The pain is localized to the right lower quadrant and is associated with nausea and vomiting. She also reports a recent onset of irregular periods. Her last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago. On physical examination, she is in acute distress and has severe tenderness in the right lower quadrant with rebound tenderness. 
This patient's symptoms are suggestive of ovarian cyst torsion. 
Ovarian cyst torsion can present with acute onset of severe unilateral lower abdominal pain. The presence of nausea and vomiting, along with the physical examination findings, support this diagnosis. The recent onset of irregular periods may suggest a hormonal cause of the ovarian cyst. 
A 13-year-old girl presents to the clinic with a 2-day history of mild lower right abdominal pain. The pain is intermittent and does not interfere with her daily activities. She denies any associated symptoms. Her last menstrual period was 1 week ago and was normal. On physical examination, she is comfortable and has mild tenderness in the right lower quadrant. 
This patient's symptoms are suggestive of an ovarian cyst. 
Ovarian cysts can cause mild, intermittent lower abdominal pain. The lack of associated symptoms and the mild physical examination findings make this diagnosis more likely in this patient. 
A 16-year-old girl presents to the emergency department with severe lower left abdominal pain that started suddenly earlier today. The pain is associated with nausea and vomiting. She also reports a history of irregular periods. Her last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago. On physical examination, she is in acute distress and has severe tenderness in the left lower quadrant with rebound tenderness. 
This patient's symptoms are suggestive of ovarian cyst torsion. 
Ovarian cyst torsion often presents with acute onset of severe unilateral lower abdominal pain. The presence of nausea and vomiting, along with the physical examination findings, support this diagnosis. The history of irregular periods may suggest a hormonal cause of the ovarian cyst.

On physical examination, she is in obvious distress and has severe tenderness in the right lower quadrant with voluntary guarding.
column4: The patient's symptoms are suggestive of ovarian cyst torsion.
column5: This condition often presents with sudden onset of severe unilateral lower abdominal pain. In this patient, the lack of systemic symptoms such as fever or changes in bowel habits makes other diagnoses like appendicitis less likely.
column6: A 12-year-old girl presents to the clinic with a 1-day history of lower left abdominal pain. The pain is dull and intermittent. She also reports mild nausea but no vomiting. She does not report any changes in bowel or bladder habits. Her last menstrual period was three weeks ago and was normal. On physical examination, she is comfortable and has mild tenderness in the left lower quadrant.
column7: This patient's symptoms are suggestive of an ovarian cyst.
column8: Ovarian cysts can be asymptomatic but may cause dull, unilateral lower abdominal pain. The intermittent nature of the pain and the lack of associated symptoms make this diagnosis more likely in this patient.
column9: A 15-year-old girl presents to the emergency department with severe lower abdominal pain that started suddenly about 6 hours ago. The pain is localized to the right lower quadrant and is associated with nausea and vomiting. She also reports a recent onset of irregular periods. Her last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago. On physical examination, she is in acute distress and has severe tenderness in the right lower quadrant with rebound tenderness.
column10: This patient's symptoms are suggestive of ovarian cyst torsion.
column11: Ovarian cyst torsion can present with acute onset of severe unilateral lower abdominal pain. The presence of nausea and vomiting, along with the physical examination findings, support this diagnosis. The recent onset of irregular periods may suggest a hormonal cause of the ovarian cyst.
column12: A 13-year-old girl presents to the clinic with a 2-day history of mild lower right abdominal pain. The pain is intermittent and does not interfere with her daily activities. She denies any associated symptoms. Her last menstrual period was 1 week ago and was normal. On physical examination, she is comfortable and has mild tenderness in the right lower quadrant.
column13: This patient's symptoms are suggestive of an ovarian cyst.
column14: Ovarian cysts can cause mild, intermittent lower abdominal pain. The lack of associated symptoms and the mild physical examination findings make this diagnosis more likely in this patient.
column15: A 16-year-old girl presents to the emergency department with severe lower left abdominal pain that started suddenly earlier today. The pain is associated with nausea and vomiting. She also reports a history of irregular periods. Her last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago. On physical examination, she is in acute distress and has severe tenderness in the left lower quadrant with rebound tenderness.
column16: This patient's symptoms are suggestive of ovarian cyst torsion.
column17: Ovarian cyst torsion often presents with acute onset of severe unilateral lower abdominal pain. The presence of nausea and vomiting, along with the physical examination findings, support this diagnosis. The history of irregular periods may suggest a hormonal cause of the ovarian cyst.

column2:
A 14-year-old girl presents to the emergency department with sudden, severe lower right abdominal pain that started a few hours ago. She describes the pain as sharp and constant, with occasional waves of increased intensity. She is sexually active and uses condoms inconsistently. Her last menstrual period was two weeks ago, and it was heavier than usual. On physical examination, she is in obvious distress. Her abdomen is tender to palpation in the lower right quadrant with rebound tenderness. Pelvic examination reveals a tender adnexal mass on the right side. 


 The girl most likely has an ovarian torsion secondary to a cyst. 


 Ovarian torsion is a common cause of severe lower abdominal pain in sexually active adolescent girls and is often associated with an ovarian cyst. The pain is usually sudden and severe, and may be associated with nausea and vomiting. 

A 12-year-old girl presents to the clinic with a complaint of intermittent lower abdominal pain for the past month, which she describes as dull and achy. She had her menarche six months ago and has had irregular periods ever since. She denies any sexual activity. Physical examination reveals a palpable mass in the lower abdomen. 


 The girl most likely has an ovarian cyst. 


 Ovarian cysts can cause intermittent lower abdominal pain and are often associated with menstrual irregularities. Irregular periods following menarche are common and may be associated with the development of functional ovarian cysts.

A 16-year-old girl presents to the emergency department with severe lower left abdominal pain that started suddenly while she was playing volleyball. She also reports nausea and vomiting. She is sexually active and uses oral contraceptives. Her last menstrual period was one week ago. On physical examination, her abdomen is tender to palpation in the lower left quadrant with rebound tenderness. Pelvic examination reveals a tender adnexal mass on the left side. 


 The girl most likely has an ovarian torsion secondary to a cyst. 


 Sudden onset of severe lower abdominal pain, especially during physical activity, is a classic presentation of ovarian torsion. Oral contraceptives reduce the risk of functional ovarian cysts, but do not eliminate the risk entirely.

A 10-year-old girl presents to the clinic with a complaint of lower abdominal pain and increased abdominal girth for the past two months. She has not yet had her menarche. Physical examination reveals a large, palpable, non-tender mass in the lower abdomen.


 The girl most likely has a large ovarian cyst. 


 Ovarian cysts can cause lower abdominal pain and increased abdominal girth, and may be palpable as a mass in the lower abdomen. Although ovarian cysts are more common in adolescents and young adults, they can occur at any age.

A 15-year-old girl presents to the emergency department with severe, sharp right lower quadrant abdominal pain that started suddenly a few hours ago while she was dancing. She also reports nausea and vomiting. She is sexually active and uses a contraceptive patch. Her last menstrual period was two weeks ago. On physical examination, her abdomen is tender to palpation in the right lower quadrant with rebound tenderness. Pelvic examination reveals a tender adnexal mass on the right side.


 The girl most likely has an ovarian torsion secondary to a cyst.


 Ovarian torsion often presents with sudden, severe lower abdominal pain, often associated with physical activity. The contraceptive patch reduces the risk of functional ovarian cysts, but does not eliminate the risk entirely.

column2:
1. A 14-year-old girl presents to the emergency department with severe, sudden onset pain in her lower right abdomen. She denies any prior similar pain. Her last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago, and it was normal. She denies sexual activity. Physical examination reveals right lower quadrant tenderness, rebound tenderness, and a palpable mass. Her temperature is 99.5F, and her heart rate is 90/min. What is the most likely diagnosis?


 Ovarian torsion

 This patient's sudden onset severe pain, associated with a palpable mass and signs of peritoneal irritation (rebound tenderness), is suggestive of ovarian torsion. 

2. A 12-year-old girl comes to the clinic with her mother complaining of intermittent, crampy abdominal pain and bloating for the last three months. Her mother reports that she started her period approximately six months ago and has had irregular bleeding since then. On physical examination, her abdomen is soft, with some tenderness in the lower quadrants. A pelvic ultrasound is performed demonstrating a unilateral ovarian cyst. What is the most likely diagnosis?


 Functional ovarian cyst

 This patient's age, recent onset of menses, and irregular bleeding are suggestive of a functional ovarian cyst, which can cause intermittent abdominal pain and bloating.

3. A 16-year-old female presents to the emergency department with severe lower abdominal pain that started suddenly about five hours ago. The pain is localized to the right lower quadrant and is associated with nausea and vomiting. She is sexually active and uses oral contraceptives. On examination, she appears in acute distress, her pulse is 110 bpm, and her temperature is 100.2F. The right lower quadrant of her abdomen is tender, and there is guarding and rebound tenderness. What is the most likely diagnosis?


 Ovarian torsion

 Given the patient's sudden onset of severe lower abdominal pain, association with nausea and vomiting, and physical findings of guarding and rebound tenderness, ovarian torsion is the most likely diagnosis.

4. A 15-year-old girl presents with a three-day history of dull, aching pain in her lower abdomen. She has also noticed an increase in the size of her abdomen over the same period. She has regular periods and denies being sexually active. On physical examination, the abdomen is distended with a palpable mass in the lower abdomen. An ultrasound shows a large complex ovarian cyst. What is the most likely diagnosis?


 Ovarian cyst

 This patient's dull, aching abdominal pain, increased abdominal girth, and ultrasound findings are suggestive of an ovarian cyst.

5. A 13-year-old girl comes to the clinic with her mother, complaining of right-sided lower abdominal pain for the past two days. The pain is constant, dull, and not related to her menstrual cycle. She has had no changes in bowel or bladder habits. On examination, there is mild tenderness in the right lower quadrant. An ultrasound of the pelvis reveals a simple ovarian cyst. What is the most likely diagnosis?


 Simple ovarian cyst

 The patient's symptoms and ultrasound findings are indicative of a simple ovarian cyst.

6. A 17-year-old girl presents to the emergency department with severe, sudden onset pain in her lower abdomen. The pain began suddenly yesterday and has not improved. She denies any prior similar pain. Her last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago, and it was normal. She has been sexually active for several months and uses condoms for contraception. Physical examination reveals right lower quadrant tenderness and a palpable mass. Her temperature is 99.5F, and her heart rate is 90/min. What is the most likely diagnosis?


 Ovarian torsion

 This patient's sudden onset severe pain, associated with a palpable mass and signs of peritoneal irritation, is suggestive of ovarian torsion.

7. A 16-year-old girl comes to the emergency department with severe lower abdominal pain that started suddenly earlier in the day. She describes the pain as sharp and says it is worst in the right lower quadrant. She also reports nausea and vomiting. On examination, she has tenderness in the right lower quadrant and a palpable mass. Her temperature is 100.4F, and her heart rate is 120/min. What is the most likely diagnosis?


 Ovarian torsion

 The patient's symptoms and physical examination findings are suggestive of ovarian torsion, a medical emergency that requires immediate surgical intervention.

8. A 15-year-old girl presents to the clinic with a two-day history of lower abdominal pain. The pain is dull and constant and is associated with bloating. She has regular periods and denies being sexually active. On physical examination, there is mild tenderness in the lower abdomen, but no palpable mass. An ultrasound of the pelvis reveals a small simple ovarian cyst. What is the most likely diagnosis?


 Simple ovarian cyst

 This patient's symptoms and ultrasound findings are indicative of a simple ovarian cyst.

9. A 14-year-old girl comes to the clinic with her mother, complaining of intermittent lower abdominal pain for the past month. The pain is not related to her menstrual cycle. She has had no changes in bowel or bladder habits. On examination, there is mild tenderness in the lower abdomen. An ultrasound of the pelvis reveals a complex ovarian cyst. What is the most likely diagnosis?


 Complex ovarian cyst

 The patient's symptoms and ultrasound findings are indicative of a complex ovarian cyst.

10. A 17-year-old girl presents to the emergency department with severe lower abdominal pain. The pain started suddenly earlier in the day and has been getting worse. She is sexually active and uses oral contraceptives. On examination, she has severe tenderness in the right lower quadrant and a palpable mass. Her temperature is 99.8F, and her heart rate is 120/min. What is the most likely diagnosis?


 Ovarian torsion

 The patient's symptoms and physical examination findings are suggestive of ovarian torsion, a medical emergency that requires immediate surgical intervention. 

11. A 13-year-old girl is brought to the clinic by her mother with complaints of lower abdominal pain and bloating. Her mother reports that her daughter has had irregular periods since they started a year ago. Physical exam reveals mild lower quadrant tenderness, but no palpable mass. An ultrasound shows a small ovarian cyst. What is the most likely diagnosis?


 Functional ovarian cyst

 The combination of the patient's age, irregular periods, and ultrasound findings suggest a functional ovarian cyst, which are common in adolescent girls.

12. A 16-year-old girl presents to the emergency department with severe lower abdominal pain that started suddenly earlier in the day. She also reports nausea and vomiting. On examination, she has tenderness in the right lower quadrant and a palpable mass. Her temperature is 100.4F, and her heart rate is 120/min. What is the most likely diagnosis?


 Ovarian torsion

 The patient's symptoms and physical examination findings are suggestive of ovarian torsion, a medical emergency that requires immediate surgical intervention.

What is the most likely diagnosis?

 This patient's dull, aching abdominal pain, increased abdominal girth, and ultrasound findings are suggestive of a simple ovarian cyst.

column2:
1. A 13-year-old African American girl presents with sudden, severe pain in her lower right abdomen. She reports that it started just a few hours ago and that she has never had such pain before. She also mentions that she started menstruating about a year ago. She is afebrile, with a blood pressure of 110/70 mmHg, heart rate of 90 beats per minute, and respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute. Abdominal examination reveals tenderness in the right lower quadrant.  
 Ovarian cyst torsion. 
 This patient's age, the acute onset of severe pain, and tenderness in the right lower quadrant are suggestive of ovarian torsion, likely due to an ovarian cyst.
2. A 15-year-old Caucasian girl comes in with a history of intermittent, unilateral pelvic pain for the past two months. She also reports irregular periods and weight gain. On physical examination, there is tenderness in her right lower quadrant. An ultrasound shows multiple small cysts in both ovaries.   
 Polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS).    
 This patient's history of irregular periods, weight gain, and bilateral ovarian cysts are indicative of PCOS.
3. A 14-year-old Hispanic girl presents with sudden, severe left lower abdominal pain that started a few hours ago. She also notes nausea and vomiting. She is sexually active and uses condoms for contraception. On examination, she is tachycardic and has tenderness and a palpable mass in the left lower quadrant.
 Ovarian cyst torsion.  
 The acute onset of severe pain, nausea, vomiting, and the palpable mass in the left lower quadrant suggest ovarian torsion.
4. A 16-year-old Asian girl presents with a 6-month history of dull, aching pain in the lower abdomen that worsens during her periods. She also reports heavy menstrual bleeding and fatigue. Physical examination reveals pallor and a palpable mass in the pelvis. 
 Hemorrhagic ovarian cyst.  
 The heavy menstrual bleeding, fatigue, and pallor suggest anemia, likely due to chronic blood loss from a hemorrhagic ovarian cyst.
5. An 8-year-old African American girl presents with sudden onset right lower quadrant pain. She also reports nausea and fever. On examination, there is rebound tenderness in the right lower quadrant.  
 Appendicitis. 
 Although an ovarian cyst could cause these symptoms, the age of the patient and the presence of rebound tenderness make appendicitis a more likely diagnosis.
6. A 17-year-old Caucasian girl presents with a three-day history of worsening right-sided abdominal pain. She also reports that her last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago. On examination, there is right lower quadrant tenderness and a palpable mass.
 Ovarian cyst.  
 The timing of the pain relative to her menstrual cycle and the palpable mass suggest an ovarian cyst.
7. An 11-year-old Hispanic girl presents with acute onset of severe lower abdominal pain that woke her from sleep. She also reports nausea and vomiting. On examination, she has tenderness and a palpable mass in the right lower quadrant.   
 Ovarian cyst torsion. 
 The acute onset of severe pain, along with the nausea, vomiting, and palpable mass, suggest ovarian torsion.
8. A 12-year-old Asian girl presents with a two-week history of lower abdominal pain that worsens during her periods. She also reports increased hair growth on her face and body. On examination, there is a palpable mass in her lower abdomen.
 Polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS).
 The lower abdominal pain that worsens during periods, along with the increased hair growth, suggest PCOS.
9. A 14-year-old African American girl presents with a one-week history of unilateral pelvic pain. She also reports that her last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago. On examination, there is right lower quadrant tenderness. 
 Ovarian cyst.  
 The timing of the pain relative to her menstrual cycle and the unilateral nature of the pain suggest an ovarian cyst.
10. A 15-year-old Caucasian girl presents with a two-day history of severe right lower quadrant pain. She also reports nausea and vomiting. On examination, she is tachycardic and has right lower quadrant tenderness.   
 Ovarian cyst torsion.   
 The acute onset of severe pain, along with the nausea, vomiting, and tachycardia, suggest ovarian torsion.
11. A 16-year-old Hispanic girl presents with a three-month history of irregular periods and lower abdominal pain. On examination, there is a palpable mass in her lower abdomen and her abdomen is distended.   
 Ovarian cyst.
    The irregular periods, lower abdominal pain, and palpable mass suggest an ovarian cyst.
12. A 13-year-old Asian girl presents with a three-day history of severe lower abdominal pain that is worse on the right side. She also reports that her last menstrual period was a week ago. On examination, there is right lower quadrant tenderness and a palpable mass.
    Ovarian cyst torsion.
    The acute onset of severe pain and the palpable mass suggest ovarian torsion.
13. A 17-year-old African American girl presents with a two-month history of irregular periods and lower abdominal pain. She also reports increased hair growth on her face and body. On examination, there is a palpable mass in her lower abdomen.
    Polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS).
    The irregular periods, lower abdominal pain, and increased hair growth suggest PCOS.
14. A 15-year-old Caucasian girl presents with a one-week history of dull, aching pain in the lower abdomen. She also reports heavy menstrual bleeding and fatigue. On examination, there is pallor and a palpable mass in the pelvis.
    Hemorrhagic ovarian cyst.
    The heavy menstrual bleeding, fatigue, pallor, and palpable mass suggest a hemorrhagic ovarian cyst.
15. A 16-year-old Hispanic girl presents with a two-day history of severe left lower quadrant pain. She also reports nausea and vomiting. On examination, she is tachycardic and has left lower quadrant tenderness.
    Ovarian cyst torsion.
    The acute onset of severe pain, along with the nausea, vomiting, and tachycardia, suggest ovarian torsion.
16. A 14-year-old Asian girl presents with a three-month history of irregular periods and lower abdominal pain. She also reports that she has gained weight. On examination, there is a palpable mass in her lower abdomen.
    Polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS).
    The irregular periods, lower abdominal pain, and weight gain suggest PCOS.

    Hemorrhagic ovarian cyst.
