An ultrasound or CT scan is needed to confirm the diagnosis.

18) A 4-year-old boy is brought in by his parents with abdominal pain, vomiting, and constipation. On examination, a large, hard mass is palpable in the abdomen. 
Neuroblastoma is suspected 
given the patient's age and symptoms. Diagnostic tests such as urine catecholamines and imaging studies can confirm the diagnosis.

19) A 5-year-old girl presents with her parents, complaining of abdominal pain, decreased appetite, and weight loss. On examination, a large mass is palpable in the right upper quadrant. 


 Hepatoblastoma, a malignant liver tumor is suspected.
 primarily affects children. Further investigation with imaging and possibly biopsy is needed to confirm the diagnosis.

20) A 16-year-old girl presents with abdominal pain and bloating. She has experienced menarche at the age of 12 and has regular menstrual cycles. On examination, a pelvic mass is palpable. 


 Ovarian tumor
although rare, can present with these symptoms in adolescent girls. An ultrasound can confirm the diagnosis.

column2:
1) A 14-year-old female teen presents to the clinic with her mother, complaining of abdominal pain and feeling full quickly after small meals. She has also noticed a swelling in her lower abdomen. On physical exam, a pelvic mass is palpated. She's also experiencing irregular menstrual cycles. 
The patient is diagnosed with an ovarian tumor. 
This is unusual in this age group, but the symptoms of early satiety, abdominal swelling, and menstrual irregularities suggest a gynecologic cause.

2) A 9-year-old boy presents with his father, stating he has been experiencing sharp pain in his right lower abdomen for the past 2 days. The pain is associated with nausea. On examination, there is tenderness in the right lower quadrant. An appendectomy is performed, and a carcinoid tumor is found.
Tumors
Carcinoid tumors are rare but can be a cause of appendicitis in children.

3) A 10-year-old girl is brought in by her mother due to a 1-week history of dull, aching abdominal pain. The pain is more severe in the right upper quadrant. She also reports dark urine. On examination, hepatomegaly is noted. 
The diagnosis is hepatocellular carcinoma. 
Hepatocellular carcinoma is rare in children, but it should be considered in the differential diagnosis of hepatomegaly and jaundice.

4) A 12-year-old boy presents with his father, complaining of a 3-week history of abdominal pain, loss of appetite, and weight loss. On examination, a mass is felt in his left upper quadrant. 
A diagnosis of Wilms' tumor is made. 
Wilms' tumor, also known as nephroblastoma, is the most common renal malignancy in children.

5) A 6-year-old girl is brought to the clinic by her mother due to a 2-week history of abdominal pain and constipation. She also reports intermittent blood in the stool. On examination, a rectal mass is palpated. 
She is diagnosed with a juvenile polyp. 
Juvenile polyps are the most common type of polyp in children, and they can cause abdominal pain and rectal bleeding.

6) A 15-year-old boy presents with his mother, complaining of a 2-week history of lower abdominal pain and changes in bowel habits. On examination, a mass is palpated in his left lower quadrant. 
He is diagnosed with a desmoid tumor. 
Desmoid tumors are rare, benign tumors that can cause abdominal pain and changes in bowel habits.

7) A 3-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her parents. She has a 1-day history of severe abdominal pain, vomiting, and a swollen abdomen. On examination, a large mass is palpated in the right lower quadrant. 
She is diagnosed with a neuroblastoma. 
Neuroblastoma is the most common extracranial solid cancer in childhood and the most common cancer in infancy.

8) A 7-year-old boy is brought in by his mother because of a 1-week history of abdominal pain and blood in his stool. On examination, a mass is palpated in his right lower quadrant. 
He is diagnosed with a Meckel's diverticulum. 
Meckel's diverticulum is a common congenital anomaly that can cause abdominal pain and gastrointestinal bleeding.

9) A 13-year-old girl presents with her father, complaining of a 2-week history of abdominal pain and early satiety. On examination, a mass is palpated in her left upper quadrant. 
She is diagnosed with a gastric adenocarcinoma. 
Gastric adenocarcinoma is rare in children, but it should be considered in the differential diagnosis of abdominal pain and early satiety.

10) A 5-year-old boy is brought in by his parents due to a 1-week history of abdominal pain and a mass in his abdomen. On examination, a large mass is palpated in his right upper quadrant. 
He is diagnosed with a hepatoblastoma. 
Hepatoblastoma is the most common liver malignancy in children.

11) A 8-year-old girl presents with her mother, complaining of a 1-week history of abdominal pain and a palpable mass in her abdomen. On examination, a mass is palpated in her right lower quadrant. 
She is diagnosed with an appendiceal mucocele. 
Appendiceal mucoceles are rare, benign tumors of the appendix that can cause abdominal pain and a palpable mass.

12) A 10-year-old boy is brought in by his father because of a 1-week history of abdominal pain and bloody diarrhea. On examination, a mass is palpated in his left lower quadrant. 
He is diagnosed with a rectosigmoid carcinoma. 
Rectosigmoid carcinoma is rare in children, but it should be considered in the differential diagnosis of abdominal pain and bloody diarrhea.

13) A 16-year-old girl presents with her mother, complaining of a 2-week history of lower abdominal pain and irregular periods. On examination, a pelvic mass is palpated. 
She is diagnosed with a granulosa cell tumor. 
Granulosa cell tumors are rare ovarian tumors that can cause lower abdominal pain and menstrual irregularities.

14) A 6-year-old boy is brought in by his parents due to a 1-week history of abdominal pain and a palpable mass in his abdomen. On examination, a large mass is palpated in his left upper quadrant. 
He is diagnosed with a renal cell carcinoma. 
Renal cell carcinoma is rare in children, but it should be considered in the differential diagnosis of abdominal pain and a palpable mass.

15) A 14-year-old girl presents with her father, complaining of a 1-week history of lower abdominal pain and changes in bowel habits. On examination, a mass is palpated in her right lower quadrant. 
She is diagnosed with a cecal carcinoma. 
Cecal carcinoma is rare in children, but it should be considered in the differential diagnosis of lower abdominal pain and changes in bowel habits.

16) A 11-year-old boy is brought in by his mother because of a 1-week history of abdominal pain and vomiting. On examination, a mass is palpated in his right upper quadrant. 
He is diagnosed with a pancreatic adenocarcinoma. 
Pancreatic adenocarcinoma is extremely rare in children, but it should be considered in the differential diagnosis of abdominal pain and vomiting.

17) A 12-year-old girl presents with her mother, complaining of a 2-week history of abdominal pain and weight loss. On examination, a mass is palpated in her left lower quadrant. 
She is diagnosed with a clear cell sarcoma of the kidney. 
Clear cell sarcoma of the kidney is a rare renal tumor in children that can cause abdominal pain and weight loss.

18) A 9-year-old boy is brought in by his father because of a 1-week history of abdominal pain and constipation. On examination, a mass is palpated in his right lower quadrant. 
He is diagnosed with a ganglioneuroma. 
Ganglioneuromas are rare, benign tumors that can cause abdominal pain and constipation.

19) A 7-year-old girl is brought to the clinic by her mother due to a 2-week history of abdominal pain and a palpable mass in her abdomen. On examination, a large mass is palpated in her right lower quadrant. 
She is diagnosed with a rhabdoid tumor of the kidney. 
Rhabdoid tumors of the kidney are rare, aggressive renal tumors in children that can cause abdominal pain and a palpable mass.

20) A 5-year-old boy presents with his father, complaining of a 1-week history of abdominal pain and loss of appetite. On examination, a mass is palpated in his right upper quadrant. 
He is diagnosed with a hepatocellular adenoma. 
Hepatocellular adenomas are rare, benign liver tumors that can cause abdominal pain and loss of appetite.

column1: Abdominal wall pain (from strain or injury)
column2:
1. A 10-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his mother for a 3-day history of abdominal pain. The pain is primarily located in the left lower quadrant and is described as a sharp, intermittent pain that worsens with movement. His mother reports that the boy fell off his bicycle last week and landed on his abdomen. On physical examination, there is tenderness on palpation at the left lower quadrant. There is no guarding, rigidity, or rebound tenderness. The abdomen is soft and bowel sounds are normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 Abdominal wall pain (from strain or injury)

 The history of trauma from the bicycle fall and localized tenderness on palpation suggest an abdominal wall injury.

2. A 14-year-old girl presents to the emergency department with her father complaining of sudden onset of severe abdominal pain. The pain is mainly in the right lower quadrant and is sharp in nature. The patient is a gymnast and experienced a fall during practice earlier in the day. On examination, there is localized tenderness in the right lower quadrant without rebound or rigidity. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 Abdominal wall pain (from strain or injury)

 The history of a recent fall and the localized pain suggest an abdominal wall injury.

3. A 7-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his mother due to a 2-day history of abdominal pain. The pain is described as crampy and is mainly in the left upper quadrant. His mother reveals that the boy had a minor car accident a week ago where he bumped his abdomen on the steering wheel. On physical examination, there is tenderness on palpation of the left upper quadrant. There is no rebound tenderness, rigidity, or guarding. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 Abdominal wall pain (from strain or injury)

 The history of abdominal trauma from the car accident and the localized pain suggest an abdominal wall injury.

4. An 8-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her mother due to a 1-day history of severe abdominal pain. The pain is localized to the right lower quadrant and is described as a constant, sharp pain. She was hit in the abdomen by a soccer ball during a game yesterday. On examination, there is localized tenderness in the right lower quadrant without rebound or rigidity. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 Abdominal wall pain (from strain or injury)

 The history of abdominal trauma from a soccer ball and the localized pain suggest an abdominal wall injury.

5. A 12-year-old boy presents to the clinic with his father complaining of a 3-day history of abdominal pain. The pain is described as a constant, dull ache in the left lower quadrant. The boy is a competitive swimmer and had a minor accident during practice last week where he hit his abdomen on the pool edge. On physical examination, there is tenderness on palpation of the left lower quadrant. There is no guarding, rigidity, or rebound tenderness. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 Abdominal wall pain (from strain or injury)

 The history of abdominal trauma from a swimming accident and the localized pain suggest an abdominal wall injury.

6. A 13-year-old girl presents to the pediatrician with her mother for a 2-day history of abdominal pain. The pain is primarily located in the right upper quadrant and is described as a sharp, intermittent pain that worsens with movement. She was playing a rough game of basketball at school and was elbowed in the abdomen. On physical examination, there is localized tenderness in the right upper quadrant without rebound or rigidity. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 Abdominal wall pain (from strain or injury)

 The history of abdominal trauma from a basketball game and the localized pain suggest an abdominal wall injury.

7. A 9-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his father due to a 1-day history of abdominal pain. The pain is described as a sharp pain in the right lower quadrant. column1: Abdominal wall pain (from strain or injury)
column2:
1. Case: A 14-year-old boy presents to the clinic with his father complaining of lower right abdominal pain that started after a football game the previous day. He reports that he was tackled quite hard and fell onto his stomach. The pain is sharp, increases with movement and coughing, but does not radiate. On physical examination, there is prominent tenderness on palpation of the right lower quadrant without rebound tenderness or guarding. Bowel sounds are normal. 


 Abdominal wall pain from strain or injury.


 The history of trauma to the abdomen during the football game, the localized pain, and the absence of signs of peritoneal irritation (rebound tenderness, guarding) make abdominal wall pain from strain or injury the most likely diagnosis.

2. Case: A 12-year-old gymnast presents with her coach with a 2-day history of persistent, constant, and sharp pain in the middle of her abdomen. The pain started after a long practice session involving many abdominal exercises. On physical exam, the pain intensifies with contraction of the abdominal muscles. There is no rebound tenderness, and bowel sounds are normal.


 Abdominal wall pain from strain or injury.


 The history of strenuous abdominal exercises and pain worsening with muscle contraction suggests abdominal wall strain.

3. Case: A 10-year-old boy comes to the clinic with his mother complaining of abdominal pain in the last 24 hours. The pain started after he fell off his bike and hit his stomach. The pain is localized to the lower left quadrant and worsens with movement. On physical examination, there is tenderness to palpation in the same area but no rebound tenderness or guarding. Bowel sounds are normal. 


 Abdominal wall pain from strain or injury.


 The history of trauma and the localized pain without peritoneal signs suggest abdominal wall pain.

4. Case: A 13-year-old girl presents with her mother complaining of abdominal pain for the past three days. She states that the pain started after she did several sit-ups for a physical education test at school. The pain is sharp, localized to the mid-abdomen, and increases with coughing and movement. On physical examination, there's tenderness on palpation of the mid-abdomen, but no rebound tenderness or guarding. Bowel sounds are normal.


 Abdominal wall pain from strain or injury.


 The history of strenuous abdominal exercise and pain that worsens with muscle contraction suggests an abdominal wall strain.

5. Case: A 16-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with his father with a complaint of severe abdominal pain. He was playing football when he was tackled and landed on his stomach. The pain is localized to the right lower quadrant, worsens with movement, and does not radiate. On physical examination, there is tenderness on palpation of the right lower quadrant, but no rebound tenderness or guarding. Bowel sounds are normal.


 Abdominal wall pain from strain or injury.


 The history of trauma, localized pain, and absence of peritoneal signs suggest abdominal wall pain.

6. Case: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother complaining of abdominal pain that started after a fall from a climbing frame at the park. The pain is sharp, localized to the left lower quadrant, and worsens with movement. On physical examination, there is tenderness on palpation of the left lower quadrant but no rebound tenderness or guarding. Bowel sounds are normal.


 Abdominal wall pain from strain or injury.


 The history of trauma and the localized pain without peritoneal signs suggest abdominal wall pain.

7. Case: A 15-year-old girl presents to the clinic with her mother complaining of a constant, sharp pain in the middle of her abdomen. She is a cheerleader and remembers feeling a sudden pain while performing an intense abdominal workout during practice the previous day. On physical exam, the pain intensifies with contraction of the abdominal muscles. There is no rebound tenderness, and bowel sounds are normal.


 Abdominal wall pain from strain or injury.


 The history of strenuous abdominal exercises and pain worsening with muscle contraction suggests an abdominal wall strain.

8. Case: A 12-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with his father complaining of severe pain in his lower right abdomen. He was at soccer practice when he was kicked in the stomach. The pain is sharp, localized, and increases with movement. On physical examination, there is prominent tenderness on palpation of the right lower quadrant without rebound tenderness or guarding. Bowel sounds are normal.


 Abdominal wall pain from strain or injury.


 The history of trauma to the abdomen during soccer practice, the localized pain, and the absence of peritoneal signs make abdominal wall pain from strain or injury the most likely diagnosis.

9. Case: A 13-year-old girl presents with her mother complaining of lower left abdominal pain that started after a gymnastics competition. The pain is sharp, localized, and worsens with movement. On physical examination, there is tenderness on palpation of the left lower quadrant but no rebound tenderness or guarding. Bowel sounds are normal.


 Abdominal wall pain from strain or injury.


 The history of strenuous physical activity in gymnastics, localized pain, and absence of peritoneal signs suggest an abdominal wall strain or injury.

10. Case: A 10-year-old boy presents to the clinic with his mother complaining of abdominal pain for the last 24 hours. The pain started after he fell off a swing and hit his stomach. The pain is localized to the lower right quadrant and worsens with movement. On physical examination, there is tenderness to palpation in the same area but no rebound tenderness or guarding. Bowel sounds are normal.


 Abdominal wall pain from strain or injury.


 The history of trauma and the localized pain without peritoneal signs suggest abdominal wall pain.

column1: Abdominal wall pain (from strain or injury)
column2:
1. A 12-year-old boy presents to the clinic with his mother complaining of persistent pain in his right lower abdomen for the past two days. He denies any vomiting, diarrhea or fever. He mentions that he fell over while playing soccer at school a few days ago, but didn't feel much pain at the time. On examination, there is tenderness over the right lower quadrant without any signs of rebound tenderness or rigidity. What is the most likely diagnosis?
 Abdominal wall pain due to strain or injury.
 The history of trauma and absence of other symptoms characteristic of appendicitis or other intra-abdominal pathology points to abdominal wall pain
2. A 5-year-old girl is brought to the clinic by her father with complaints of abdominal pain for the last 24 hours. The pain is localized in the left lower quadrant. She has no history of fever, vomiting, or diarrhea. She fell off her bicycle yesterday and has been in pain since then. On examination, there is tenderness in the left lower quadrant, but no rebound tenderness or guarding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
 Abdominal wall pain due to strain or injury.
 Despite the location of the pain, the history of trauma and lack of systemic symptoms suggest an injury to the abdominal wall rather than an intra-abdominal process.
3. An 8-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother with complaints of abdominal pain for the past few hours. The pain is localized to the right upper quadrant. He has no history of fever, vomiting, or diarrhea. He was hit in the abdomen while playing football earlier today. On physical examination, there is tenderness in the right upper quadrant, but no signs of peritonitis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
 Abdominal wall pain due to strain or injury.
 The history of trauma and localized pain without signs of peritonitis suggests an abdominal wall injury.
4. A 10-year-old girl presents to the clinic with her father complaining of severe pain in her lower abdomen that started suddenly while she was practicing gymnastics. She has no history of fever, vomiting, or diarrhea. On examination, there is tenderness and mild swelling in the lower abdomen, but no rebound tenderness or guarding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
 Abdominal wall pain due to strain or injury.
 The sudden onset of pain during physical activity and the lack of systemic symptoms suggest an abdominal wall strain or injury
5. A 7-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother with complaints of pain in the left upper quadrant of his abdomen, which started after he fell off his skateboard earlier today. He has no history of fever, vomiting, or diarrhea. On physical examination, there is localized tenderness in the left upper quadrant, but no signs of peritonitis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
 Abdominal wall pain due to strain or injury.
 The history of trauma and the absence of systemic symptoms suggest an abdominal wall injury.
6. A 6-year-old girl presents to the clinic with her father complaining of abdominal pain that started after she was punched in the stomach by her older brother. She has no history of fever, vomiting, or diarrhea. On examination, there is tenderness and mild bruising over the right lower quadrant, but no signs of peritonitis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
 Abdominal wall pain due to strain or injury. 
 The history of trauma and the absence of systemic symptoms suggest an abdominal wall injury.
7. A 13-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with his mother complaining of severe pain in his lower abdomen that started suddenly while he was lifting heavy boxes. He has no history of fever, vomiting, or diarrhea. On examination, there is tenderness and mild swelling in the lower abdomen, but no rebound tenderness or guarding. What is the most likely diagnosis?  
 Abdominal wall pain due to strain or injury.
The sudden onset of pain during physical activity and the lack of systemic symptoms suggest an abdominal wall strain or injury.
8. A 9-year-old boy presents to the clinic with his father complaining of pain in his left lower abdomen that started after he fell off his scooter earlier today. He has no history of fever, vomiting, or diarrhea. On physical examination, there is localized tenderness in the left lower quadrant, but no signs of peritonitis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Abdominal wall pain due to strain or injury.
 The history of trauma and the absence of systemic symptoms suggest an abdominal wall injury.
9. A 11-year-old girl presents to the clinic with her mother complaining of persistent pain in her upper abdomen for the past two days. She denies any vomiting, diarrhea or fever. She mentions that she fell over while ice skating at school a few days ago, but didn't feel much pain at the time. On physical examination, there is tenderness over the upper quadrant without any signs of rebound tenderness or rigidity. What is the most likely diagnosis?
 Abdominal wall pain due to strain or injury.
 The history of trauma and absence of other symptoms characteristic of appendicitis or other intra-abdominal pathology points to abdominal wall pain.
10. A 14-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with his father complaining of severe pain in his lower abdomen that started suddenly while he was practicing wrestling. He has no history of fever, vomiting, or diarrhea. On physical examination, there is tenderness and mild swelling in the lower abdomen, but no rebound tenderness or guarding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Abdominal wall pain due to strain or injury.   
The sudden onset of pain during physical activity and the lack of systemic symptoms suggest an abdominal wall strain or injury.

column1: Abdominal wall pain (from strain or injury)
column2:
1. A 9-year-old boy presents to the clinic with pain in his lower abdomen for the past 2 days. His mother reports that he fell off the jungle gym at school, landing on his belly. He denies any nausea, vomiting, or changes in bowel movements. Physical examination reveals tenderness to palpation over the lower abdomen with a slight bulge. The rest of the examination is unremarkable. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 Abdominal wall pain due to injury with possible abdominal wall hernia.

 The history of trauma followed by pain and a bulge suggests a possible abdominal wall injury leading to a hernia.

2. A 15-year-old male football player comes to the clinic complaining of sharp pain in the right lower quadrant of his abdomen. He explains that the pain started during practice yesterday when he did some abdominal exercises. He denies any nausea, vomiting, or changes in bowel habits. On examination, his abdomen is flat, and there is tenderness on palpation of the right lower quadrant without any guarding or rebound tenderness. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 Abdominal wall pain due to muscle strain.

 Abdominal wall pain due to a muscle strain is common in athletes, especially after intense exercise. 

3. A 10-year-old girl presents to the clinic with her mother because of a 2-day history of abdominal pain. The mother explains that her daughter fell down the stairs two days ago and has been complaining of pain ever since. On physical examination, there is tenderness and a small bruise on the lower abdomen. The rest of her examination is unremarkable. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 Abdominal wall pain due to injury.

 The history of falling down the stairs followed by abdominal pain and a bruise suggests abdominal wall injury.

4. A 13-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother due to abdominal pain that started yesterday. He says the pain is around his belly button and worsened after he had a wrestling match at school. On examination, there is tenderness over the umbilical region, but no signs of inflammation or hernia. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 Abdominal wall pain due to strain.

 The history of wrestling followed by pain around the umbilicus suggests abdominal muscle strain.

5. A 14-year-old girl presents to the emergency department with severe lower abdominal pain following a fall from her bicycle. Her physical examination reveals tenderness and bruising over the lower abdomen, but no signs of internal injury. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 Abdominal wall pain due to injury.

 The history of trauma from a fall and physical examination findings of tenderness and bruising are consistent with an abdominal wall injury.

6. A 16-year-old boy presents with pain in his lower left abdomen that started after a soccer game yesterday. On physical examination, there is localized tenderness over the left lower quadrant without any guarding or rebound. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 Abdominal wall pain due to muscle strain.

 The history of playing soccer followed by localized abdominal pain suggests a muscle strain.

7. A 9-year-old girl comes to the clinic with her mother due to abdominal pain for the last 3 days. The mother mentions that her daughter fell off the swing at the playground and landed hard on her belly. There is tenderness on palpation of the lower abdomen and a slight bulge. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 Abdominal wall pain due to injury with possible abdominal wall hernia.

 The history of trauma and the physical examination findings suggest an abdominal wall injury leading to a hernia.

8. An 11-year-old boy presents to the clinic with a 1-day history of abdominal pain. He reports that the pain started after he did several sit-ups during his physical education class. Physical examination reveals tenderness over the midline of the abdomen. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 Abdominal wall pain due to strain.

 The history of intense exercise followed by abdominal pain suggests an abdominal muscle strain.

9. A 12-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents due to abdominal pain that started after a football game yesterday. His physical examination reveals tenderness over his lower right abdomen, but no signs of inflammation or hernia. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 Abdominal wall pain due to muscle strain.

 The history of playing football followed by localized abdominal pain suggests a muscle strain.

10. A 15-year-old girl presents to the clinic with her mother due to a 1-day history of right lower abdominal pain. The mother mentions that her daughter was doing gymnastics yesterday. On physical examination, there is localized tenderness over the right lower quadrant without any guarding or rebound. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 Abdominal wall pain due to muscle strain.

 The history of gymnastics followed by localized abdominal pain suggests a muscle strain.

11. A 14-year-old boy presents with abdominal pain that started after lifting heavy boxes yesterday. He describes the pain as sharp and localized to the right lower quadrant of his abdomen. Physical examination reveals tenderness over the right lower quadrant without any guarding or rebound. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 Abdominal wall pain due to muscle strain.

 The history of lifting heavy objects followed by localized abdominal pain suggests a muscle strain.

12. A 10-year-old girl presents to the emergency department with severe lower abdominal pain following a fall on the playground at school. Her physical examination reveals tenderness and bruising over the lower abdomen, but no signs of internal injury. What is the most likely diagnosis?

What is the most likely diagnosis?
column55: Abdominal wall pain due to muscle strain.
column56: The history of moving heavy furniture followed by localized abdominal pain suggests a muscle strain.
column57: 19. A 10-year-old girl presents to the emergency department with severe lower abdominal pain following a fall while rollerblading. Her physical examination reveals tenderness and bruising over the lower abdomen, but no signs of internal injury. What is the most likely diagnosis?
column58: Abdominal wall pain due to injury.
column59: The history of trauma from a fall and physical examination findings of tenderness and bruising are consistent with an abdominal wall injury.
column60: 20. A 16-year-old boy presents with pain in his lower left abdomen that started after a wrestling match yesterday. On physical examination, there is localized tenderness over the left lower quadrant without any guarding or rebound. What is the most likely diagnosis?
column61: Abdominal wall pain due to muscle strain.

column1: Abdominal wall pain (from strain or injury)
column2:
1) A 7-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with his mother. He complains of acute abdominal pain that began after a football match earlier in the day. The mother says he was tackled hard during the game. On examination, there is localized tenderness and mild swelling over the lower right abdomen. There is no rebound tenderness or rigidity, and bowel sounds are normal.

 Abdominal wall strain from injury. 
The history of trauma and localized signs without peritoneal irritation suggest muscular strain or bruising.

2) A 13-year-old gymnast is brought in by her coach with a complaint of abdominal pain for the past 2 days. She has been practicing a new routine with many twists and turns. She points to the pain being on the left side of her abdomen. On examination, she winces with palpation but there is no guarding or rebound tenderness.

 Abdominal wall strain from overuse. 
The history of intense exercise and localized pain without peritonitis suggest muscular overuse.

3) A 9-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his parents. He has been complaining of abdominal pain for the past three days. The pain is located on his right side. The parents note that the boy had a minor fall from his bicycle three days ago. On examination, the child exhibits tenderness on deep palpation of the right lower quadrant with no rebound tenderness.

 Abdominal wall injury from the fall. 
The history of trauma and localized pain without peritoneal signs suggest an abdominal wall injury.

4) A 15-year-old girl presents with her mother complaining of abdominal pain that started after doing multiple sit-ups during her physical education class yesterday. The pain is located in the center of her abdomen, around the umbilicus. On examination, she has tenderness over the midline abdomen without guarding or rebound.

 Rectus abdominis strain from exercise. 
The history and examination suggest a muscular strain.

5) A 12-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother complaining of pain in the lower left side of his abdomen. The mother mentions that the boy had a wrestling match yesterday. On examination, there is tenderness and mild bruising over the lower left abdomen, but no signs of peritoneal irritation.

 Abdominal wall injury from wrestling. 
The history of trauma and localized findings suggest a muscular injury.

6) A 14-year-old girl who is a competitive swimmer presents with her father complaining of abdominal pain for the past week. She describes the pain as a constant, dull ache on her right side. On examination, there is tenderness over the right lateral abdomen without guarding or rebound.

 Abdominal wall strain from swimming. 
The history of intense exercise and localized pain suggest muscular strain.

7) A 10-year-old boy is brought in by his parents with a complaint of abdominal pain. The boy fell during a basketball game at school yesterday and landed on his stomach. On examination, there is tenderness and mild swelling over the upper right abdomen, but no signs of peritoneal irritation.

 Abdominal wall injury from the fall. 
The history of trauma and localized findings suggest a muscular injury.

8) A 16-year-old girl presents with her mother complaining of left lower abdominal pain for the past 2 days. She is a ballet dancer and has been rehearsing for a performance. On examination, there is tenderness over the lower left abdomen without guarding or rebound.

 Abdominal wall strain from dancing. 
The history of intense exercise and localized pain suggest a muscular strain.

 Abdominal wall injury from the fall. 
The history of trauma and localized pain suggest an abdominal wall injury.

column2:
1. A 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because he has been complaining of right lower quadrant pain for the past two days. The pain is associated with a slight fever and diarrhea. His mother states that his pain is worse after meals. On physical examination, his abdomen is mildly distended and there is tenderness in the right lower quadrant. 


The answer is Mesenteric Adenitis. 
The child's symptoms, particularly the right lower quadrant pain, mimic those of appendicitis but the history of diarrhea suggests an infectious cause.

2. A 7-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department with a one-day history of abdominal pain. The pain is mainly in the lower abdomen and is accompanied by a mild fever. She also complains of nausea but no vomiting. On examination, she appears uncomfortable and there is tenderness in the right lower quadrant. 


The answer is Mesenteric Adenitis. 
The presence of fever and right lower quadrant pain may suggest appendicitis, but the lack of other signs such as vomiting and the quick onset suggest mesenteric adenitis.

3. A 6-year-old boy presents with a 2-day history of right-sided abdominal pain. The pain is crampy in nature and is associated with loose stools. He has no history of fever, vomiting, or urinary symptoms. On physical examination, there is tenderness in the right lower quadrant and mild rebound tenderness. 


The answer is Mesenteric Adenitis. 
The presentation may be confusing with appendicitis, but the lack of fever and the presence of diarrhea suggest mesenteric adenitis.

4. A 12-year-old girl is brought to the hospital with a 3-day history of abdominal pain and diarrhea. The pain is located in the right lower quadrant and is associated with a low-grade fever. She has a past medical history of irritable bowel syndrome. On physical examination, there is tenderness in the right lower quadrant. 


The answer is Mesenteric Adenitis. 
Despite the patient's history of IBS, the presence of fever and RLQ pain suggests an infectious process, likely mesenteric adenitis.

5. A 9-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with a 1-day history of right lower quadrant pain. The pain is severe in nature and is associated with fever and vomiting. On examination, he appears ill and there is tenderness in the right lower quadrant. 


The answer is Mesenteric Adenitis. 
The presentation may be confusing with appendicitis, but the quick onset and the severe nature of the symptoms suggest mesenteric adenitis.

6. A 10-year-old girl is brought to the doctor with a 2-day history of abdominal pain and diarrhea. The pain is located in the right lower quadrant and is associated with a low-grade fever. On physical examination, there is tenderness in the right lower quadrant. 


The answer is Mesenteric Adenitis. 
The presence of fever and RLQ pain with diarrhea suggest an infectious process, likely mesenteric adenitis.

column2:
1. A 6-year-old boy presents with his mother, complaining of acute abdominal pain that started last night. The mother reports a low-grade fever and lack of appetite. The boy is writhing in pain, and physical examination reveals tenderness in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen. There is no rebound tenderness or rigidity, and bowel sounds are normal. What is the most likely diagnosis? 


 Mesenteric adenitis. 


 The symptoms are consistent with mesenteric adenitis, which often mimics appendicitis. However, lack of rebound tenderness or rigidity and normal bowel sounds make appendicitis less likely. 

2. A 10-year-old girl is brought in by her father due to a three-day history of abdominal pain. The girl also reports having had a sore throat and cough a week ago. On physical examination, the pain is localized in the right lower quadrant, and there is no guarding or rigidity. She is afebrile. Her father denies any vomiting or changes in bowel movements. What is the most likely diagnosis?


 Mesenteric adenitis.


 Mesenteric adenitis often follows a recent upper respiratory infection and can mimic appendicitis with right lower quadrant pain. However, the lack of peritoneal signs (guarding or rigidity) and afebrile status suggest mesenteric adenitis.

3. An 8-year-old boy presents with intermittent lower abdominal pain for the past two days. His mother states he has had a decreased appetite and mild diarrhea. On physical examination, the child appears uncomfortable but not in severe pain. There is tenderness in the right lower quadrant without rebound or guarding. What is the most likely diagnosis?


 Mesenteric adenitis.

column2:
1) A 10-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his father with a complaint of severe abdominal pain for the past 2 hours. The pain is focused in the lower right quadrant and is associated with nausea but no vomiting. Past medical history is unremarkable. He has a low-grade fever. On physical examination, there is tenderness in the right lower quadrant. Appendicitis is suspected. How should this case be managed?


 The boy should undergo ultrasonography to rule out appendicitis and confirm mesenteric adenitis. 


 Mesenteric adenitis can mimic appendicitis, presenting with similar symptoms. However, in mesenteric adenitis, the pain is often diffuse rather than localized. 

2) A 9-year-old girl presents to the pediatric clinic with a 3-day history of abdominal pain, fever, and vomiting. She had a sore throat a week ago. On examination, the abdomen is soft with tenderness in the right lower quadrant. The white blood cell count is slightly elevated. What is the most likely diagnosis?


 The most likely diagnosis is mesenteric adenitis.


 Mesenteric adenitis is common in children and often follows an upper respiratory tract infection. Symptoms include abdominal pain, fever, and vomiting. 

3) A 12-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with a 1-day history of diffuse abdominal pain that has localized to the right lower quadrant. He also reports a recent upper respiratory infection. On physical examination, there is rebound tenderness in the right lower quadrant. What is the most likely diagnosis?


 The most likely diagnosis is mesenteric adenitis.


 The history of a recent upper respiratory infection, along with the abdominal pain that has localized to the right lower quadrant, is suggestive of mesenteric adenitis.

 The most likely diagnosis is mesenteric adenitis.


 Mesenteric adenitis often follows an upper respiratory tract infection and presents with symptoms such as fever, abdominal pain, and vomiting.

column32: Mesenteric adenitis often follows a respiratory infection and presents with symptoms such as fever, abdominal pain, and vomiting.
column33: 11) A 15-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with a 1-day history of diffuse abdominal pain that has localized to the right lower quadrant. He also reports a recent upper respiratory infection. On physical examination, there is rebound tenderness in the right lower quadrant. What is the most likely diagnosis?
column34: The most likely diagnosis is mesenteric adenitis.
column35: The history of a recent upper respiratory infection, along with the abdominal pain that has localized to the right lower quadrant, is suggestive of mesenteric adenitis.
column36: 12) A 5-year-old girl presents to the pediatric clinic with a 3-day history of abdominal pain, fever, and vomiting. She had a sore throat a week ago. column37: The most likely diagnosis is mesenteric adenitis.
column38: Mesenteric adenitis is common in children and often follows an upper respiratory tract infection. Symptoms include abdominal pain, fever, and vomiting.
column39: 13) A 12-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his father with a complaint of severe abdominal pain for the past 2 hours. On physical examination, there is tenderness in the right lower quadrant. Appendicitis is suspected. How should this case be managed?
column40: The boy should undergo ultrasonography to rule out appendicitis and confirm mesenteric adenitis.
column41: Mesenteric adenitis can mimic appendicitis, presenting with similar symptoms. However, in mesenteric adenitis, the pain is often diffuse rather than localized.

column2:
1. A 9-year-old girl presents to the clinic with her mother complaining of abdominal pain and weight loss. She mentions a recent episode of diarrhea that lasted for a day. Her mother notes that she has been more tired than usual and her appetite has decreased. Physical examination reveals tenderness in the right lower quadrant of her abdomen. The mother denies any history of similar symptoms or any family history of gastrointestinal diseases. 
The most likely diagnosis is mesenteric adenitis. 
This is a condition characterized by inflammation of the lymph nodes in the mesentery, which can mimic appendicitis. 

2. A 12-year-old boy is brought in by his father due to complaints of abdominal pain for the past two days. The boy also reports having a mild fever and nausea. On examination, there is tenderness in the right lower quadrant, but no rebound tenderness. The boy has no prior history of similar symptoms. 
The probable diagnosis is mesenteric adenitis, 
can present with similar symptoms as appendicitis but is often preceded by upper respiratory infection symptoms.

3. A 10-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with his parents. He has been complaining about severe abdominal pain that started suddenly in the middle of the night. The pain is located in the lower right quadrant. The boy also reports a slight fever and a sore throat that started a few days ago. On physical examination, he shows signs of discomfort and tenderness in the right lower quadrant but no guarding or rebound. 
The most likely diagnosis is mesenteric adenitis, 
a condition that can mimic appendicitis but is often associated with recent upper respiratory tract infections. 

4. An 11-year-old girl is brought to the clinic by her mother, who reports that her daughter has been complaining of abdominal pain for the past three days. The girl also mentions a recent sore throat and runny nose. On examination, the girl has tenderness in the right lower quadrant but does not exhibit rebound tenderness. 
The most probable diagnosis is mesenteric adenitis
inflammation of the lymph nodes in the mesentery often associated with viral infections.

5. A 6-year-old boy presents with his parents to the emergency department with a complaint of abdominal pain. The pain has been ongoing for two days and is located in the right lower quadrant. He also has a loss of appetite and a low-grade fever. On physical exam, the right lower quadrant is tender but there is no rebound or rigidity. 
This presentation is most likely mesenteric adenitis
often mistaken for appendicitis but lacks the severe rebound tenderness or rigidity.

6. A 7-year-old girl comes to the clinic with her father, reporting abdominal pain that has been present for the past day. The pain is located in the right lower quadrant and is accompanied by a mild fever. She also mentions recent episodes of diarrhea. On examination, tenderness is noted in the right lower quadrant but without rebound tenderness. 
The likely diagnosis is mesenteric adenitis
inflammation of the lymph nodes in the mesentery that can mimic appendicitis.

The most probable diagnosis is mesenteric adenitis
a condition that can mimic appendicitis but often lacks the severe rebound tenderness or guarding of appendicitis. 

8. A 14-year-old girl presents to the clinic with complaints of right lower quadrant abdominal pain for the past two days. The girl also mentions a recent upper respiratory tract infection. On examination, there is tenderness in the right lower quadrant but no rebound or rigidity. 
The most likely diagnosis is mesenteric adenitis
an inflammation of the lymph nodes in the mesentery often associated with recent viral infections.

column2:
1. A 6-year-old girl is brought to the pediatrician by her mother who reports the child has been complaining of pain in the right lower side of her abdomen for the past 24 hours. The child has a temperature of 100.4 F. On examination, the girl appears uncomfortable with tenderness on palpation in the right lower quadrant. Her labs show a slight elevation in white blood cell count. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 Mesenteric adenitis.

 The symptoms presented by this child ??right lower quadrant abdominal pain and slightly elevated white blood cell count ??are consistent with mesenteric adenitis, an inflammation of the lymph nodes in the mesentery of the abdomen.

2. A 12-year-old boy visits the clinic with his father. The father mentions that his son has had a fever for the past 3 days and complains of pain in his belly. The boy looks pale and is found to have right lower quadrant tenderness on physical examination. His white blood cell count is within normal limits. What could be the most likely diagnosis?

 Mesenteric adenitis.

 Mesenteric adenitis can present with similar symptoms to appendicitis, including right lower quadrant abdominal pain. It typically occurs after a viral infection, and unlike appendicitis, it is not always associated with an elevated white blood cell count.

3. An 8-year-old boy is brought into the ER by his mother who reports that her son has been having abdominal pain and vomiting for the last 48 hours. The child has a fever of 101.3 F. On physical examination, the boy is in discomfort with tenderness in the right lower quadrant. Blood tests reveal leukocytosis. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 Mesenteric adenitis.

 Mesenteric adenitis is a common cause of right lower quadrant pain in children. The presence of fever, vomiting, and leukocytosis further supports this diagnosis.

4. A 10-year-old girl presents to the clinic with her mother. The mother reports that the child has been complaining of abdominal pain that seems to move around but is mainly located in the right lower quadrant. On physical examination, the girl has tenderness in the right lower quadrant. Her white blood cell count is slightly elevated. What could be the most probable diagnosis?

 Mesenteric adenitis.

 The right lower quadrant pain and slightly increased white blood cell count are indicative of mesenteric adenitis.

 Mesenteric adenitis.

 The symptoms, including right lower quadrant abdominal pain, slightly increased white blood cell count, and fever, are suggestive of mesenteric adenitis.

 Mesenteric adenitis.

column2:
1. A 6-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with his parents who report that he has been experiencing abdominal pain for the past two days. The pain is associated with vomiting and decreased appetite. He also has a rash on his lower legs, buttocks, and arms which appeared a day after the abdominal pain started. The rash is non-blanching and purpuric. He also complains of joint pain in the knees and ankles. His previous medical history is unremarkable. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 Henoch-Sch?nlein purpura

 The clinical presentation of abdominal pain, purpuric rash, and joint pain are consistent with Henoch-Sch?nlein purpura (HSP), a small-vessel vasculitis that typically presents in children.

2. An 8-year-old girl presents to your clinic with her mother, complaining of abdominal pain and joint pain in her knees and ankles. She also has a rash on her legs and buttocks. Her mother mentions a recent upper respiratory infection. The girl's urine dipstick shows trace amounts of blood. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 Henoch-Sch?nlein purpura

 HSP often follows an upper respiratory infection and presents with abdominal pain, arthralgia, and a purpuric rash. Hematuria can also occur due to renal involvement.

3. A 4-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his parents who report that he has been experiencing severe abdominal pain for the past three days. He also has joint pain and a rash on his legs and buttocks. His parents also mention that he has had dark-colored stools. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 Henoch-Sch?nlein purpura

 HSP can present with abdominal pain, joint pain, purpuric rash, and melena (dark-colored stools) due to gastrointestinal bleeding.

4. A 10-year-old girl presents to the pediatrician's office with her father, complaining of abdominal pain and joint pain in her knees and ankles. She also has a rash on her legs and buttocks, and her father mentions that she has had a few episodes of bloody urine. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 Henoch-Sch?nlein purpura

 HSP can present with abdominal pain, arthralgia, purpuric rash, and hematuria due to renal involvement.

5. A 7-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents who report that he has been experiencing severe abdominal pain for the past two days. He has vomited several times and has a decreased appetite. He also has a rash on his legs and buttock and complains of joint pain. His parents mention a recent streptococcal throat infection. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 Henoch-Sch?nlein purpura

 HSP often follows a streptococcal infection and presents with abdominal pain, vomiting, decreased appetite, joint pain, and a purpuric rash.

6. A 5-year-old girl presents to the pediatric clinic with her mother, complaining of abdominal pain and joint pain in her knees and ankles. She also has a rash on her legs. Her mother mentions a recent bout of flu-like symptoms. The girl's urine shows proteinuria and hematuria on dipstick. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 Henoch-Sch?nlein purpura

 HSP often follows a viral illness and can present with abdominal pain, arthralgia, purpuric rash, proteinuria, and hematuria due to renal involvement.

column2:
1. A 9-year-old Hispanic boy is brought to the clinic by his mother with complaints of abdominal pain, especially after meals. His mother also reports that he has had intermittent bouts of nausea and vomiting for the past week. On physical examination, the child has a palpable purpuric rash on his lower extremities. His mother also mentions that he had a respiratory infection two weeks ago. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 Henoch-Sch?nlein purpura. 
This condition often follows an upper respiratory infection and presents with abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and palpable purpura.

2. A 7-year-old African-American girl is brought to the ER by her parents due to severe abdominal pain and bloody stools for the past two days. She also has a rash on her lower extremities. On physical examination, the rash appears to be palpable purpura. She has a history of recent upper respiratory tract infection. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 Henoch-Sch?nlein purpura. 
The child's symptoms of abdominal pain, bloody stools, and palpable purpura following a recent upper respiratory infection are typical of this condition.

3. A 10-year-old Caucasian boy presents to the clinic with abdominal pain and a rash on his lower extremities. He also complains of pain in his knees and ankles. He had a sore throat and runny nose a week ago. On examination, the rash is palpable and purpuric. He has a history of allergies but no other significant medical history. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Henoch-Sch?nlein purpura. 
The boy's symptoms of abdominal pain, joint pain, palpable purpura, and recent upper respiratory infection suggest this condition.

4. An 8-year-old Asian girl is brought to the clinic by her parents due to abdominal pain and a rash on her lower extremities. She also has had vomiting and bloody stools for the past two days. She had a fever and cough two weeks ago. On examination, the rash is palpable and purpuric. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Henoch-Sch?nlein purpura. 
The girl's symptoms of abdominal pain, vomiting, bloody stools, palpable purpura, and recent upper respiratory infection are characteristic of this condition.

5. A 6-year-old Caucasian boy presents to the clinic with severe abdominal pain, accompanied by nausea and vomiting. He also has a rash on his lower extremities. His parents report that he had a cold a week ago. On examination, the rash is palpable and purpuric. What is the most likely diagnosis?

column2:
1) An 8-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his parents who report that their son has been experiencing severe abdominal pain for the past two days. His mother also noticed a rash on his legs earlier that day that she describes as "red and blotchy." The boy has no history of allergies or recent illnesses. On physical examination, the doctor notes a purpuric rash on the boy's lower extremities. The pediatrician also notes that the boy is tender in the right lower quadrant of his abdomen. 
The boy is diagnosed with Henoch-Sch?nlein purpura. 
The abdominal pain is likely due to bowel wall inflammation caused by the disease.

2) A 7-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain that began suddenly a few hours ago. column2:
1. A 7-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with his mother, who reports that her son has been experiencing diffuse abdominal pain over the last two days, which he describes as "sharp" and "worse after eating." His mother also mentions that he had an upper respiratory tract infection two weeks ago. On physical examination, you notice non-blanching petechial rash on his lower extremities and buttocks. 
 Henoch-Sch?nlein purpura (HSP)
 HSP is often preceded by an upper respiratory tract infection and presents with a triad of palpable purpura, arthritis/arthralgia, and abdominal pain. 
2. A 9-year-old girl comes to the clinic accompanied by her father. She complains of pain in her knees and ankles for the last three days and abdominal pain for the past day. She also reports having a rash on her legs. On examination, you find palpable purpura on her lower extremities.
 Henoch-Sch?nlein purpura
 The presence of arthritis/arthralgia, abdominal pain, and palpable purpura, especially in children, is suggestive of HSP.
3. A 6-year-old boy is brought to your clinic by his mother. She says that he has been complaining of abdominal pain for the past two days and has been passing dark urine. On examination, you notice a palpable purpura on his legs and buttocks and mild edema in his lower extremities.
Henoch-Sch?nlein purpura
The combination of abdominal pain, palpable purpura, and renal involvement (dark urine, edema) are indicative of HSP.
4. A 5-year-old girl presents to the emergency department with her parents. She has been experiencing severe abdominal pain for the past day, accompanied by vomiting and bloody stools. Her mother mentions a recent episode of a mild cold. On examination, you find a non-blanching rash on her lower extremities and buttocks.
Henoch-Sch?nlein purpura
HSP can present with severe abdominal pain, vomiting, and bloody stools due to intestinal vasculitis. The rash and recent infection are also typical of HSP.
5. An 8-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his father. He complains of joint pain in his knees and ankles, abdominal pain, and blood in his urine. On examination, you find palpable purpura on his lower extremities.
Henoch-Sch?nlein purpura
The presence of arthritis/arthralgia, abdominal pain, renal involvement (hematuria), and palpable purpura are indicative of HSP.
6. A 10-year-old girl presents to the emergency department with her mother, complaining of severe abdominal pain and vomiting. She also reports joint pain in her knees and ankles. On examination, you notice a non-blanching rash on her lower extremities and buttocks.
Henoch-Sch?nlein purpura
The combination of severe abdominal pain, vomiting, arthritis/arthralgia, and palpable purpura are all characteristic of HSP.
7. A 7-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his parents. He has been complaining of abdominal pain and bloody stools for the past two days. His parents also report a recent upper respiratory infection. On examination, you find palpable purpura on his legs and buttocks.
Henoch-Sch?nlein purpura
HSP often follows an upper respiratory infection and presents with abdominal pain, bloody stools, and palpable purpura.

column2:
1. A 5-year-old Caucasian male is brought to the ER by his mother for sudden-onset abdominal pain. He also has a rash on his lower extremities and buttocks that appeared suddenly. The mother reports recent upper respiratory infection. Physical examination reveals palpable purpura on lower extremities and buttocks. He appears to be in significant pain. 
 Henoch-Sch?nlein purpura (HSP). 
 The combination of abdominal pain, palpable purpura, and history of a recent upper respiratory infection are classic findings in HSP.

2. A 7-year-old African American male presents to the pediatrician for abdominal pain for the past 3 days. His mother also notes a rash on his legs for the same duration. On physical examination, you note purpura on his legs and buttocks. He also has ankle swelling. 
 Henoch-Sch?nlein purpura. 
 The presence of abdominal pain, purpura, and arthritis (as evidenced by ankle swelling) suggest HSP.

3. A 10-year-old Asian female is rushed to the ER for severe abdominal pain and vomiting. She has a history of a recent upper respiratory infection. You note purpura on the lower extremities. 
 Henoch-Sch?nlein purpura. 
 The combination of abdominal pain, purpura, and a recent upper respiratory infection is suggestive of HSP.

4. A 6-year-old Hispanic male presents with abdominal pain and bloody stools. His mother also notes a purpuric rash on his legs and buttocks. Physical examination reveals palpable purpura. 
 Henoch-Sch?nlein purpura. 
 The presence of abdominal pain, bloody stools, and purpura suggest HSP.

5. A 4-year-old Caucasian female presents with abdominal pain, vomiting, and a rash on her legs. Her parents also report joint pain. On physical examination, you note purpura on her legs and buttocks. 
 Henoch-Sch?nlein purpura. 
 These symptoms are consistent with HSP, which commonly presents with abdominal pain, vomiting, rash, and joint pain.

6. A 9-year-old African American female presents with abdominal pain, bloody stools, and a rash on her legs. Her parents also report a recent upper respiratory infection. On physical examination, you note purpura on her legs and buttocks. 
 Henoch-Sch?nlein purpura. 
 These symptoms are consistent with HSP, which commonly presents after a recent upper respiratory infection.

column39: 13. A 6-year-old Caucasian male is rushed to the ER for severe abdominal pain and vomiting. He has a history of a recent upper respiratory infection. You note purpura on the lower extremities.
column41: The combination of abdominal pain, purpura, and a recent upper respiratory infection is suggestive of HSP.
column42: 14. An 8-year-old African American male presents with abdominal pain and bloody stools. His mother also notes a purpuric rash on his legs and buttocks. Physical examination reveals palpable purpura.
column44: The presence of abdominal pain, bloody stools, and purpura suggest HSP.

column47: These symptoms are consistent with HSP, which commonly presents with abdominal pain, vomiting, rash, and joint pain.

column50: These symptoms are consistent with HSP, which commonly presents after a recent upper respiratory infection.

column53: These symptoms are consistent with HSP, which commonly presents with abdominal pain, vomiting, and purpura.

column56: These symptoms are consistent with HSP, which commonly presents with abdominal pain, rash, and joint pain.

column1: Drug side effects or poison ingestion
column2:
1) A 5-year-old African American boy presents to the emergency room with his mother, who reports that he has been complaining of abdominal pain for the past 2 hours. The pain is severe and generalized. She also noticed that he vomited once and has been unusually drowsy. On physical examination, the boy's abdomen is tender to palpation. His mother recalls that he was playing in the garage earlier today where she stores cleaning supplies. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 Acute poisoning, possibly from ingestion of a cleaning product.

 The sudden onset of symptoms, the location of the pain, and the history of potential exposure to poisonous substances strongly suggest acute poisoning.

2) A 14-year-old Caucasian girl with a history of type 1 diabetes is brought to your clinic by her mother, who reports that her daughter has been complaining of abdominal pain and nausea for the past few days. She has also been unusually thirsty and urinating frequently. On physical examination, the girl's abdomen is soft and non-tender. Her breath has a fruity odor. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 Diabetic ketoacidosis.

 The symptoms of abdominal pain, nausea, polydipsia, polyuria, and a fruity odor to the breath are classic for diabetic ketoacidosis, a potentially life-threatening complication of type 1 diabetes.

3) A 10-year-old Asian boy is brought to your clinic by his father, who reports that his son has been complaining of abdominal pain for the past 3 days. The pain is worse after meals and is associated with nausea. He also reports that his son was recently started on NSAIDs for juvenile rheumatoid arthritis. On physical examination, the boy's abdomen is tender to palpation in the epigastric area. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 NSAID-induced peptic ulcer disease.

 The symptoms of postprandial abdominal pain and nausea, along with the recent initiation of NSAID therapy, strongly suggest peptic ulcer disease.

4) A 7-year-old Hispanic girl is brought to your clinic by her mother, who reports that her daughter has been complaining of abdominal pain and has had several episodes of vomiting. She also noticed that her daughter's urine has been dark and her skin appears yellow. On physical examination, the girl's abdomen is soft and non-tender. Her sclerae are noticeably yellow. The mother reports that the girl was recently started on a new medication for epilepsy. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 Drug-induced hepatitis.

 The symptoms of abdominal pain, vomiting, dark urine, and jaundice, along with the recent initiation of a new medication, suggest drug-induced hepatitis.

5) A 16-year-old Caucasian boy presents to the emergency room with his father, who reports that his son has been complaining of severe abdominal pain for the past 6 hours. The pain is localized to the right lower quadrant. The boy also has a fever and has vomited twice. On physical examination, the boy's abdomen is tender to palpation in the right lower quadrant. The father reports that the boy was recently started on isotretinoin for severe acne. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 Acute appendicitis.

 The symptoms of localized right lower quadrant pain, fever, and vomiting are classic for acute appendicitis. Although isotretinoin can cause abdominal pain, the localized pain and fever suggest a more serious condition.

6) A 12-year-old African American girl is brought to your clinic by her mother, who reports that her daughter has been complaining of abdominal pain and diarrhea for the past week. She also noticed that her daughter's skin appears pale. On physical examination, the girl's abdomen is soft and non-tender. The mother reports that the girl was recently started on a new medication for sickle cell disease. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 Drug-induced hemolytic anemia.

 The symptoms of abdominal pain, diarrhea, and pallor, along with the recent initiation of a new medication, suggest drug-induced hemolytic anemia.

7) A 9-year-old Caucasian boy is brought to your clinic by his father, who reports that his son has been complaining of abdominal pain and has had several episodes of vomiting. He also noticed that his son's skin appears flushed and he seems restless. On physical examination, the boy's abdomen is soft and non-tender. The father reports that the boy was playing in his grandfather's room earlier today, where he keeps his medications. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 Acute poisoning, possibly from ingestion of a medication.

 The symptoms of abdominal pain, vomiting, flushed skin, and restlessness, along with the potential exposure to medications, suggest acute poisoning.

8) A 15-year-old Asian girl presents to the emergency room with severe abdominal pain. She also reports feeling dizzy and has vomited multiple times. On physical examination, her abdomen is diffusely tender and she appears to be in distress. Her mother reports that the girl has been taking large amounts of a weight loss supplement she bought online. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 Acute poisoning due to overdose of a weight loss supplement.

 The symptoms of severe abdominal pain, vomiting, and dizziness, along with the history of taking a potentially dangerous substance, suggest acute poisoning.

9) A 6-year-old Hispanic boy is brought to your clinic by his mother, who reports that her son has been complaining of abdominal pain and has had multiple episodes of diarrhea. She also noticed that her son appears lethargic. On physical examination, the boy's abdomen is soft and non-tender. The mother reports that the boy was recently started on a new medication for ADHD. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 Drug-induced diarrhea.

 The symptoms of abdominal pain, diarrhea, and lethargy, along with the recent initiation of a new medication, suggest drug-induced diarrhea.

10) A 13-year-old African American girl presents to the emergency room with severe abdominal pain. She also reports feeling light-headed and has vomited several times. On physical examination, her abdomen is diffusely tender and she appears pale. Her mother reports that the girl was recently started on a new medication for her asthma. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 Drug-induced gastrointestinal bleeding.

 The symptoms of severe abdominal pain, vomiting, light-headedness, and pallor, along with the recent initiation of a new medication, suggest drug-induced gastrointestinal bleeding.

column1: Drug side effects or poison ingestion
column2:
1. A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of severe abdominal pain. His mother says he woke up in the middle of the night crying and clutching his stomach. She also noticed that he vomited twice and had a fever. Upon examination, his abdomen is tender to palpation, especially in the right lower quadrant. His mother mentions that she recently started giving him over-the-counter ibuprofen for teething pain. What could be the cause of his symptoms?


 Ibuprofen-induced gastritis. 
The child's symptoms, along with the recent use of ibuprofen, suggest this diagnosis. Ibuprofen can cause gastritis and peptic ulcer disease, leading to abdominal pain, vomiting, and fever.

2. A 5-year-old girl is brought to the clinic by her father due to recurrent abdominal pain. She has had diarrhea for the past 3 days and has vomited once. She has been lethargic and lost her appetite. Her father says she recently started taking a new medication for her seizures. On exam, her abdomen is soft and tender to palpation, with hyperactive bowel sounds. What is the most likely diagnosis?


 Valproic acid toxicity. 
This girl's symptoms suggest toxicity from the new seizure medication, likely valproic acid, which can cause gastrointestinal disturbances, lethargy, and anorexia.

3. A 7-year-old boy presents with sudden onset of severe abdominal pain following dinner. He also reports nausea and vomiting. His mother says he has been taking antibiotics for a recent ear infection. On physical examination, his abdomen is rigid and diffusely tender. What is the most probable diagnosis?


 Antibiotic-associated pseudomembranous colitis. 
The boy's symptoms suggest this condition, which is commonly caused by Clostridium difficile infection following the use of antibiotics.

4. A 12-year-old girl is brought to the clinic by her mother due to abdominal pain. She also has been experiencing nausea, vomiting, and headache. Her mother mentions that she has been using an acne cream recently. On physical exam, she appears pale and has a tender abdomen. What is the most likely cause of her symptoms?


 Salicylate poisoning. 
Topical salicylates can be absorbed through the skin and cause systemic effects, such as nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and headache. 

5. A 10-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of severe abdominal pain and vomiting. The mother mentions that he takes medication for his ADHD. On examination, his pulse is 110/min, and his blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg. His abdomen is tender to palpation. What is the most probable diagnosis?


 Stimulant toxicity. 
The boy's symptoms, along with the hypertension and tachycardia, suggest toxicity from his ADHD medication, likely a stimulant.

6. A 14-year-old girl presents with severe abdominal pain, vomiting, and diarrhea. She recently started taking a new medication for her depression. On physical examination, her abdomen is soft but tender to palpation. What is the most likely diagnosis?


 Serotonin syndrome. 
This girl's symptoms suggest serotonin syndrome, possibly caused by her new antidepressant medication.

7. A 6-year-old girl is brought to the emergency room by her parents due to severe abdominal pain and vomiting. She has a history of asthma and has been using an inhaler frequently. Upon physical examination, her pulse is 120/min, and she is in visible distress. Her abdomen is tender to palpation. What is the most likely cause of her symptoms?


 Albuterol overdose. 
The girl's symptoms, along with her history of asthma and frequent inhaler use, suggest albuterol overdose, which can cause tachycardia, abdominal pain, and vomiting.

8. A 4-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother due to abdominal pain and vomiting. The mother mentions that he has been taking an antibiotic for an ear infection. On examination, his abdomen is soft but tender to palpation. What is the most likely diagnosis?


Amoxicillin-clavulanate induced hepatotoxicity. 
The boy's symptoms, along with the recent use of amoxicillin-clavulanate, suggest this diagnosis. This antibiotic can cause hepatotoxicity, leading to abdominal pain and vomiting.

9. A 9-year-old girl presents with abdominal pain, vomiting, and diarrhea. She has a history of epilepsy and has been taking a new medication. On physical examination, her abdomen is tender to palpation. What is the most likely diagnosis?


 Lamotrigine-induced gastrointestinal upset. 
The girl's symptoms suggest gastrointestinal upset caused by her new epilepsy medication, likely lamotrigine.

10. A 7-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department due to abdominal pain and vomiting. He has a history of ADHD and recently started a new medication. On examination, his heart rate is 130/min, and his abdomen is tender to palpation. What is the most probable diagnosis?


 Methylphenidate toxicity. 
The boy's symptoms, along with tachycardia, suggest toxicity from his ADHD medication, likely methylphenidate.

11. A 13-year-old girl is brought to the clinic by her mother due to recurrent abdominal pain. The mother mentions that she has been taking an over-the-counter medication for her acne. On examination, the girl appears pale, and her abdomen is tender to palpation. What is the most likely cause of her symptoms?


 Benzoyl peroxide-induced gastritis. 
The girl's symptoms, along with the recent use of benzoyl peroxide, suggest this diagnosis. This acne medication can cause gastritis, leading to abdominal pain.

12. A 5-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department due to severe abdominal pain. His mother mentions that he has been taking a medication for his asthma. On examination, his pulse is 120/min, and his abdomen is tender to palpation. What is the most probable diagnosis?
Theophylline toxicity. 
The boy's symptoms, along with tachycardia, suggest toxicity from his asthma medication, likely theophylline.

13. A 14-year-old girl is brought to the clinic due to abdominal pain, vomiting, and diarrhea. She has a history of migraines and has been taking a new medication. On physical examination, her abdomen is tender to palpation. What is the most likely diagnosis?


Triptan-induced gastrointestinal upset. 
The girl's symptoms suggest gastrointestinal upset caused by her new migraine medication, likely a triptan.

14. A 6-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department due to severe abdominal pain. His mother mentions that he has been taking an over-the-counter medication for his allergies. On examination, his abdomen is tender to palpation. What is the most probable diagnosis?


Diphenhydramine toxicity. 
The boy's symptoms, along with the recent use of diphenhydramine, suggest this diagnosis. This antihistamine can cause gastrointestinal disturbances, leading to abdominal pain.

15. A 10-year-old girl is brought to the clinic by her mother due to abdominal pain. She also has been experiencing nausea, vomiting, and a headache. Her mother mentions that she has been using a medicated shampoo for her dandruff. On physical exam, she appears pale, and her abdomen is tender. What is the most likely cause of her symptoms?


Selenium sulfide poisoning. 
Selenium sulfide, found in some medicated shampoos, can be absorbed through the skin and cause systemic effects, such as nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and headache.

16. A 8-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of severe abdominal pain and vomiting. The mother mentions that he takes medication for his ADHD. On examination, his pulse is 120/min, and his blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg. His abdomen is tender to palpation. What is the most probable diagnosis?


 Atomoxetine toxicity. 
The boy's symptoms, along with the hypertension and tachycardia, suggest toxicity from his ADHD medication, likely atomoxetine.

17. A 7-year-old girl presents with severe abdominal pain, vomiting, and diarrhea. She recently started taking a new medication for her depression. On physical examination, her abdomen is soft but tender to palpation. What is the most likely diagnosis?


 Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) syndrome. 
This girl's symptoms suggest SSRI syndrome, possibly caused by her new antidepressant medication.

18. A 4-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother due to abdominal pain and vomiting. The mother mentions that he has been taking an antibiotic for a skin infection. On examination, his abdomen is soft but tender to palpation. What is the most likely diagnosis?


 Clindamycin-induced pseudomembranous colitis. 
The boy's symptoms, along with the recent use of clindamycin, suggest this diagnosis. This antibiotic can cause pseudomembranous colitis, leading to abdominal pain and vomiting.

19. A 9-year-old girl presents with abdominal pain, vomiting, and diarrhea. She has a history of epilepsy and has been taking a new medication. On physical examination, her abdomen is tender to palpation. What is the most likely diagnosis?


Topiramate-induced gastrointestinal upset. 
The girl's symptoms suggest gastrointestinal upset caused by her new epilepsy medication, likely topiramate.

20. A 7-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department due to abdominal pain and vomiting. He has a history of ADHD and recently started a new medication. On examination, his heart rate is 130/min, and his abdomen is tender to palpation. What is the most probable diagnosis?


Amphetamine toxicity. 
The boy's symptoms, along with tachycardia, suggest toxicity from his ADHD medication, likely an amphetamine.
